title: QuakerInfo.com Forum :: View topic - What Is It With The Quakers and Jesus Christ?
text:
QuakerInfo.com Forum :: View topic - What Is It With The Quakers and Jesus Christ?



			QuakerInfo.com Forum
A place to discuss Quakers and Quakerism 
  
					 FAQ   Search   Memberlist   Usergroups 
						 Register 
						
	 Profile   Log in to check your private messages   Log in 
	  Return to QuakerInfo. com home page





		



	What Is It With The Quakers and Jesus Christ?

	  Goto page  Previous  1, 2

	    



	   	   QuakerInfo.com Forum Forum Index
	  -> Quaker Discussion



	View previous topic :: View next topic  
	Author	Message
	Shay



Joined: 01 Jun 2005
Posts: 306

		Posted:  Mon Aug 22, 2005 8:02 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	Also see: 


http://www.fgcquaker.org/library/racism/billbrown.html





It says it much better than I could.


	Back to top		      



	
	valar2006



Joined: 21 Jul 2005
Posts: 1

		Posted:  Mon Aug 22, 2005 6:44 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	I agree!


	Back to top		      



	
	thanhkim



Joined: 27 Jul 2005
Posts: 27
Location: U.S.
		Posted:  Mon Aug 22, 2005 10:06 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	So how do we get from here to there?  How do we reevaluate what our focus is, return to Christ and meet others as equals?  And, a question, what hinders the change?





I struggle with these ideas in my own church, Baptist background.  I think churches tend to cling to ritual and structure to the loss of the gospel.  If it is based on Christ, there shouldn't have to be racial divisions.  All are equal under God and in the same condition.





Honestly, not being from Quaker background, I see a lot of potential in the Quaker meeting to do this.... more than a church that relies heavily on the Sunday morning sermon.  It seems that the meeting has built into it more equality and community of people meeting God together.   More vulnerability and the awareness of our need for each other and God.  At least this is what I see as possibilities.


	Back to top		      



	
	BillSamuel



Joined: 06 Aug 2002
Posts: 524
Location: Silver Spring, MD, USA
		Posted:  Tue Aug 23, 2005 5:25 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	In unprogrammed meetings, there is often a very great emphasis on the form of the worship service, as great or greater than in churches known for being highly liturgical.  As unity on the content of faith has crumbled, Friends often cling particularly tenaciously to the form as a source of unity.





I have heard countless times unprogrammed Friends express fear that if "they" came in they would want to change the form, or that Friends would need to change the form to get "them" to come.  I have a couple of reactions to this:





1.  The stereotypes are not as true as the holders of the stereotypes think.


2.  Is form or substance more important?


3.  If we truly believe that there is God in each person, and God does not make distinctions based on such externals as color and ethnic background, wouldn't we be more concerned with living out that faith understanding than with holding rigidly to any form, no matter how useful we have found the form?
_________________
Bill Samuel, Silver Spring, MD, USA


Co-Coordinator, Friends in Christ


	Back to top		      



	
	james



Joined: 11 Jun 2004
Posts: 576
Location: Minneapolis
		Posted:  Wed Aug 24, 2005 8:21 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	
	Quote:
	In unprogrammed meetings, there is often a very great emphasis on the form of the worship service, as great or greater than in churches known for being highly liturgical. As unity on the content of faith has crumbled, Friends often cling particularly tenaciously to the form as a source of unity. 








I have heard this claim made many times by conservative Friends, in many cases specifically to justify a return to traditional Protestant forms which has occurred in those Friends' meetings or churches. It doesn't hold water. The "form" liberal Friends tend to focus on is in fact the practice of silent worship out of which any can speak. The form of this practice is in fact formlessness, the relative absence of ritual aside from sitting together, an open space into which spirit is invited to flow. I would not and do not criticize programmed or semi-programmed worship as an valid variation on Quaker tradition, but in fact either of these are clearly more focused on form than unprogrammed worship. One potential effect of programming is that the worship is shaped by those who assume authority over the meeting/church, rather than by the spirit moving in/through any who attend a particular meeting. To describe such programming as a lesser focus on form is untrue and a distraction from programmed Friends' own renewed focus on form.





Regarding the welcoming of minorities to Friends Meetings, of course it is crucial that we genuinely welcome those who come through our doors, including those who might change our practice over time, or immediately by speaking out of the silence. Such change has always occurred. Sometimes, the nature of the change will make a meeting, or the society of Friends at large, less comfortable for long-time attenders. This can be a sad event. On the other hand, if, for instance, Black folks do not attend our meetings because the practice of silent worship feels culturally alien to them, that's OK. It is culturally alien to many of them. For us to pre-emptively change our worship and start raising the rafters with rollicking Gospel tunes like the Baptists in order to attract more Baptists, would just be silly and dishonest. It is not our job to change our religion to attract more Black people, but to  be open and welcoming as we can within our integrity.


	Back to top		      



	
	thanhkim



Joined: 27 Jul 2005
Posts: 27
Location: U.S.
		Posted:  Thu Aug 25, 2005 8:17 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	
	Quote:
	As unity on the content of faith has crumbled, Friends often cling particularly tenaciously to the form as a source of unity. 








I was wondering if you could go into this...  I think it is an insightful point that I also see as a root for clinging to form among the more mainstream church background.  Maybe more so to the lack of community I often find.


	Back to top		      



	
	McGuffey



Joined: 22 Sep 2005
Posts: 154
Location: Long Beach, Ca.
		Posted:  Fri Sep 23, 2005 8:24 am    Post subject: Quaker diversity at Meetings...	   
	

	One of the main tenants of the Quaker tradition is that as an organization, we do not seek out, or recruit membership.   The traditition is one in which people have come to Meeting seeking, on thier own, the unique experience of religious tolerance, opposition to violence and war, and to bear witness against social and political injustice.   That William Penn was held in prison, and eventualy released to found the Ameican Quaker Movement, is often lost in our current discussion of Quaker life.   Yes, Quaker Meetings can go out and sell salvation through Jesus Christ, but they would end up reducing the Quaker experience to something undistinguishable from other Christian sects.   The practice of enjoining individual religious experience with active participation in non violent witnessing of injustice has always been one of the core values of Quakers, and should not be shelved for any individual search for eternal salvation.


	Back to top		      



	
	BillSamuel



Joined: 06 Aug 2002
Posts: 524
Location: Silver Spring, MD, USA
		Posted:  Fri Sep 23, 2005 9:05 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	The tradition is to proclaim the Everlasting Gospel far and wide.  This was not for the purpose of increasing membership organizationally, although it had that effect, but to present the Truth for people to consider whether their hearts responded to that as authentically from the Spirit.





The early Friends were proselytizers, and they were proselytizing about the living Christ as present Teacher, who is one and the same as Jesus of Galilee.  They held "threshing meetings" at which the Gospel was proclaimed, and the wheat accepted it and the chaff did not.  The "Valiant Sixty" spread the Everlasting Gospel far and wide.
_________________
Bill Samuel, Silver Spring, MD, USA


Co-Coordinator, Friends in Christ


	Back to top		      



	
	McGuffey



Joined: 22 Sep 2005
Posts: 154
Location: Long Beach, Ca.
		Posted:  Fri Sep 23, 2005 2:15 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	I'm sorry to disagree with you Bill, but your viewpoint seems oriented towards current Fundamentalist and Evangelical movements which have have a rather distorted view of the reasons early Quakers were persucuted.   They were rejecting the same structured and politically correct forms of worhip that you erringly advocate.  That there is a God spirit that occupies the hearts of all men in universal brotherhood is best expounded by the writings of Quaker Brother, John Woolman- "There is a principle that is pure, placed in the human mind, which in different places and ages hath different names.  It is however, pure and proceeds from God.  It is deep and inward, confined to no forms of religion nor excluded from any, where the heart stands in perfect sincerity".  I belive that you name Christ as that God force for YOUR inner light.  George Fox stated "Walk cheerfully over the world, answering that of God in everyone".   While born out of the Christian tradition, we should all be accepting that there are individual voices and callings that have names- and no names- which are equally valid religious experiences.


	Back to top		      



	
	Dave Thomas



Joined: 07 Nov 2003
Posts: 39

		Posted:  Sun Sep 25, 2005 9:36 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	I don’t see any necessary conflict between the last two posts.  I posted the following quote from Barclay’s Apology in another thread (from proposition 6 on Universal Redemption).  It bears repeating, not because we have to accept Barclay as gospel, but because it explains the traditional Quaker position, which makes a whole lot of sense to me;





“I confess that there is no other name by which to be saved.  But salvation does not lie in the literal knowledge of that name, but in the experience of what it signifies.  Those who merely know his name, without any real experience of its meaning, are not saved by it. But those who know the meaning and have experienced his power can be saved without knowing his name.”





Elsewhere, Barclay makes it clear that he believes that anyone who has accepted the spirit and who then learns about the historical Jesus Christ, will accept Him in name as well as in spirit.  The fact that many who identify themselves as Christians abuse the name of Christ should not cloud our thinking one way or the other.  Quakers, in spite of their differences, have an important testimony for Christians and non-Christians alike – a testimony of humility, simplicity and obedience to the essence of what Christ taught.  I consider myself “Christ centered”, or at least I am trying to be Christ centered, but I have fundamental differences from my Evangelical Christian friends and neighbors.  I believe we can accept Christ without rejecting His manifestations in other cultures and other ages.





If we have something important to say, why shouldn’t we tell others.  That doesn’t mean that we should tell people they are going to hell, or be otherwise arrogant.  The idea that Quakers shouldn’t proselytize is a  modern development, found only in some branches of Quakerism.  I think even the more liberal branches of Quakerism have now started to realize that not only is it OK to proselytize, but it is necessary.  Otherwise, we are withholding a perspective that few others can provide.


	Back to top		      



	
	james



Joined: 11 Jun 2004
Posts: 576
Location: Minneapolis
		Posted:  Sun Sep 25, 2005 4:09 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	
	Quote:
	Elsewhere, Barclay makes it clear that he believes that anyone who has accepted the spirit and who then learns about the historical Jesus Christ, will accept Him in name as well as in spirit. 








This is logically equivalent to saying, no one who knows about the historical Jesus and does not believe in his divinity, can be truly living in the spirit of Christ. Which is to say, Muslims and Jews are living contrary to the spirit. And this is a statement that Barclay directly and clearly denied in his writings. So, either Barclay contradicted his own universalist statements, or he did not agree with your statement above. I am not certain which is the case.





I do believe that there is a sort of proselytizing that is consistent with the genuine universalist spirit of early Quakerism. It is not the sort that proclaims Christian dogma or doctrine, but the sort that proclaims the way of living that Christ represented for them.


	Back to top		      



	
	BillSamuel



Joined: 06 Aug 2002
Posts: 524
Location: Silver Spring, MD, USA
		Posted:  Sun Sep 25, 2005 6:19 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	I unite with Dave Thomas. I fully agree with the Barclay quote.  I think McGuffey partly misunderstood me, and partly misunderstands the Quaker tradition.





In response to James, I think he's taking a too narrow view of what Barclay said. Barclay wrote about the meaning of Jesus Christ. I'm not sure what he wrote necessarily applies to someone who has heard words about the historical Jesus Christ, but in a way that obscures or even contradicts the true meaning of Christ. I don't think Barclay was talking about a formulaic presentation of Christ.





At any rate, we mortals can't really know for sure the ultimate fate of others, or exactly how God views them. We need some humility about that, although recognizing that sometimes we may be given the gift of discernment and led to speak prophetically about someone.





Early Quaker proselytizing certainly proclaimed the Gospel of Jesus Christ. This involved who Christ Jesus is, elaborated as to various offices by Fox and others, as well as the implications as to how we live our lives.
_________________
Bill Samuel, Silver Spring, MD, USA


Co-Coordinator, Friends in Christ

	James said;






	Quote:
	This is logically equivalent to saying, no one who knows about the historical Jesus and does not believe in his divinity, can be truly living in the spirit of Christ. Which is to say, Muslims and Jews are living contrary to the spirit. And this is a statement that Barclay directly and clearly denied in his writings. So, either Barclay contradicted his own universalist statements, or he did not agree with your statement above. I am not certain which is the case. 








I agree that this can be seen as a contradiction.  Dogmatic Christians have created lots of rules and regulations about what it means to accept Christ, and about what it means to be divine.  I don’t know what divinity means other than being fully united in spirit with God.  I have had discussions about Christ with many “non-Christians”, and have found that most accept Christ, within the context of their own beliefs.  Many Hindus believe that Christ was an avatar of God, along with Rama and Krishna, the Koran teaches that Jesus was one of the great prophets preceding Mohammed, and many Buddhists accept that Christ was an enlightened being like the Buddha.  Have they accepted Christ or not?  I am not going to judge.  I do believe that anyone who learns of the pure example of selfless love that was Jesus, and who has recognized the same love in their own heart, will accept Christ, maybe not in some pre-defined, dogmatic way, but in the way that really matters.

	I do believe that anyone who learns of the pure example of selfless love that was Jesus, and who has recognized the same love in their own heart, will accept Christ, maybe not in some pre-defined, dogmatic way, but in the way that really matters.








This speaks to my heart, and I am glad to hear it. Nonetheless, for many a Muslim or Jew or a Jewish nontheist Quaker such as myself, making an affirmation such as "I accept Christ" would amount to a violation of personal and spiritual integrity. In my case, it feels more honest to affirm that my highest aspiration is to care for others and our world with all my heart and mind and being. I can't say that I succeed, at least not as often as I hope, but it is my aspiration.

title: BUPA’s response to the consultation document on Regulation
text:
BUPA’s response to the consultation document on RegulationBUPA’s response to the Department of Health consultation on the future regulation of 
health and adult social care in England 
Introduction 
 
BUPA is a broadly based health and care organisation which manages health and 
social care operations in England regulated by the Healthcare Commission and CSCI 
respectively. As an insurer, we also have an interest in the standards which are 
applied to health services and in the regulation of NHS commissioning services. 
BUPA operates health and social care facilities in Spain and provides health 
insurance services around the world.  This experience from other countries informs 
our comments on the consultation document. 
 
BUPA welcomes the amalgamation of the health and social care quality regulators. 
We supported this at the time of the Care Standards Act in 2000. We also broadly 
welcome the Government’s proposals on professional regulation. However we are 
concerned that the economic aspects of regulation have not been fully addressed in 
these proposals.   
 
BUPA supports consistent quality standards for all providers. As the independent 
1
report commissioned by the Department says: “minimum quality assurance/licensing 
models must be harmonised across the public and independent sectors.” 
 
We support the delegation of competition issues from the Department of Health to an 
independent body and their separation from the NHS management chain of 
command including SHAs. The Department of Health needs to consistently see its 
role as ‘hands-off’ standard-setting for the health and care system, rather than 
regulation. Proposals need to reflect the growing ‘three-sector’ nature of services and 
be even-handed across NHS, independent and voluntary sectors.  
 
We have a particular concern on quality grounds about the current exclusion of some 
cosmetic services providers from registration by the Healthcare Commission. 
Providers of services which include injection of cosmetic fillers and/or Botox should 
be registered and inspected to ensure public confidence in quality assurance. We 
recommend that these types of provider should be registered as soon as possible. 
There are also other anomalies at present such as the difference in standards 
applied to independent hospital providers compared with private patient units within 
NHS and Foundation Trusts.  
 
Structure of this response 
 
This response is set out in four sections: an overview, specific proposals, detailed 
comments on the document, and answers to the consultation questions. BUPA is 
happy to publicise this response and to engage in further debate with stakeholders  
about these important issues. 
 
Duncan Innes 
Public Affairs Manager 
BUPA House 
15-19 Bloomsbury Way 
London 
WC1A 2BA 020 7656 2600
                                                 
1
 The Future of Health and Adult Social Care Regulation 23 November 2006 
http://www.dh.gov.uk/PublicationsAndStatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidanceArticle/fs/
en?CONTENT_ID=4140889&chk=oZ%2Be8y 
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
1
   
1. Overview 
 
In our view, the regulation of health and social care should be approached from three 
related perspectives: institutional quality assurance, economic and competition 
issues, and professional standards. This consultation mainly addresses the first and 
second perspectives, but needs to bear in mind links with professional standards as 
part of an overall system. DH policy on quality regulation also has to dovetail with 
allied policies such as Choice, Payment by Results and Practice-Based 
Commissioning. We await the Commissioning Framework and proposed guidance on 
competition principles, with interest. 
 
The regulatory system should fulfil the following criteria: 
 
• Assuring patients and the public that public services are safe, efficient, of an 
agreed high standard of quality, and provide good value for money 
 
• Correcting market failures and facilitating incentives for optimal provider 
performance within a fair competitive framework 
 
• Balancing the conflicting priorities of cost, service quality and scope of service 
 
2
• Meeting the statutory criteria for Better Regulation - that is, being 
proportionate, consistent, transparent, and targeted only at cases in which 
action is needed  
 
The background to this issue includes a historic realisation that quality assurance in 
health care is vital but that professional self-regulation has had high-profile failures, 
and institutional regulation has sometimes taken a ‘tick-box’ inspection approach. We 
welcome the Government’s proposals to address public confidence in professional 
regulation in the recent White Paper. We also welcome the constructive moves of 
CSCI and the Healthcare Commission towards a more risk-based inspection regime 
which supports good outcomes. We fully support moves to address these issues and 
so aim for a world-class regulatory system in the UK.  
 
In principle, BUPA believes that the regulatory system should: 
 
1. always maintain its focus on the outcomes of health and social care for 
individuals 
 
2. address  input, output and process measures as means towards the end of 
improved outcomes, not as ends in themselves 
 
3. balance the interests of the taxpayer, providers and commissioners of care 
but make the interests of the individual patient or client paramount 
 
4. set  fair rules for competition for all types of provider and commissioners 
 
5. minimise cost and burden on providers and commissioners, consistent with 
assuring the public that health and social care are efficient, effective and 
economical 
 
                                                 
2
 Legislative and Regulatory Reform Act 2006 S.2  
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
2
  These views are based on BUPA’s international experience and on research, as well 
as our experience of the recent evolution of quality assurance and inspection 
regimes for health and social care in the UK. 
 
Outcomes 
 
There is a great opportunity to move the regulatory system towards monitoring 
outcomes rather than processes. Any revision to the Care Standards Act should take 
this approach. This does require a clear vision of how to measure and assure quality 
of outcomes in both health and social care. The Government should consult widely 
on this as a first step, rather than move rapidly to a revised Act, when the current 
legislation has only lasted seven years. Regulation addressing outcomes must 
include commissioners and their role in contracting must be clearly differentiated 
from the proposed Regulator’s role. 
 
Input and process measures 
 
The current Standards for Better Health and statutory standards for social care tend 
to focus on inputs and some processes, rather than on outcomes. While patient 
safety must be assured, the approach of inspecting premises to see that they 
conform to fixed norms is stifling innovation. It also pre-empts investment decisions 
because the first priority for new investment must be to meet existing statutory 
standards.  
 
Standards for commissioners are at an even earlier stage of development but must 
be developed and aligned with standards for providers. 
 
Making the patient or client’s interests paramount 
 
The quality assurance system which has evolved since the Care Standards Act 2000 
does not always operate under this principle. The Health and Safety Commission’s 
inspection regime has also created a punitive culture which seeks to detect 
infringements and penalise the organisation. The requirements of the Healthcare 
Commission, CSCI, the Health and Safety Inspectorate and other government 
agencies sometimes conflict. BUPA therefore welcomes moves to re-energise the 
Inspection Concordat between the inspectorates. 
 
Fair rules for competition 
 
Health and social care markets will always be relatively heavily regulated for good 
reasons: protecting individuals and the public from harm, ensuring consistency and 
coverage of services, and assuring value for money. But an inconsistent arena for 
competition has emerged from recent policy changes. Proposals should aim to 
improve this situation and harness the benefits of competition, while avoiding the 
harm of anti-competitive practices. The role of commissioners is crucial in this 
process and so their regulation must pay regard to competition issues. 
 
Minimising costs and burdens 
 
Despite the rhetoric, the experience of the last ten years is of rising costs and 
burdens of regulation upon providers. Some benefits like consistent minimum 
standards rightly incur costs. Quality regulators such as the Healthcare Commission 
and CSCI have to be paid for.  It is unfair that NHS providers do not currently bear 
these inspection costs, while independent providers do. This anomaly must also be 
cleared up. 
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
3
   
 
 
2. Specific proposals 
 
We now make a raft of specific proposals under the headings of fair competition, 
improving health care and aligning social care standards. These comments have to 
be seen in the light of very recent Government proposals on professional regulation, 
which we have not yet had time to fully digest. 
 
Fair competition 
 
The proposed new Regulator for health and social care should assure quality and 
value for money but should not police competition. The Office of Fair Trading should 
continue to oversee competition in health and social care markets. NHS bodies such 
as Strategic Health Authorities and PCTs should have no role in monitoring 
competition as this provokes a conflict of interest. Monitor’s role with respect to NHS 
Foundation Trusts should be restricted to supporting the evolution of NHS Trusts to 
fully self-sufficient status as FTs. 
 
Improving health care standards 
 
The Regulator should over time move towards a consensus on assuring healthcare 
outcome standards. This clearly should involve the revised professional regulatory 
bodies. The timescale for laying Regulations under an Act does not allow for the 
necessary reflection and experimentation to set up a lasting framework of standards. 
Providers in the independent sector have already seen three generations of 
standards in recent years. Changes in standards are a hidden cost and burden on 
providers. The Regulator should therefore be enabled to take the time to get 
standards right. The Bill which is proposed is fundamental to quality and must be built 
on a lasting consensus. 
 
For both hospital and social care environments, the Government needs to ensure 
that standards are not set by a multitude of bodies with varying interests, but 
controlled by a single body that incorporates all necessary views.  We support ideas 
of a ‘gatekeeper’ regulator to help ensure this. This issue is especially relevant with 
the advent of the Information Centre and its potential overlap with the Healthcare 
Commission. 
 
Aligning social care standards 
 
The process of setting and improving standards in social care should not be derailed 
by the proposed merger of CSCI with the Healthcare Commission. Social care 
workers are understandably nervous of medical dominance of an amalgamated 
Regulator. A parallel process of defining outcome standards for social care should be 
undertaken with a smooth transition from the existing input-based standards over a 
period of years. No single set of combined health and social care standards is going 
to satisfy the various stakeholders. Two sets of standards – health and social care -
should remain in place but with some convergence, based on consensus, over time. 
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
4
   
3. Comments on the document 
 
In this section we comment on detailed points made in the document: 
 
1.8 Regulation needs to be risk-based: at present, there are pressures for CSCI 
and the Healthcare Commission to focus their energies on low-risk issues. 
For example, hospitals which have good clinical governance face more 
scrutiny than single-handed independent GPs.  
 
1.9 As noted above, the parallel consideration of professional regulation and of 
patient safety/incident reporting all needs to form part of one new system. 
 
1.13 The full title of the Healthcare Commission is ‘Commission for Healthcare 
Audit and Inspection’; however the financial audit of services has remained 
with the Audit Commission. Both organisations should have a focus on value 
for money. We note there is little in the document about the Audit 
Commission and that the proposed roles suggested for it in the independent 
report have not been adopted. 
 
1.16 The integration of the Mental Health Act Commission into the proposed new 
Regulator must not dilute the focus on mental health issues. 
 
1.19 It is not clear how the alignment of the assessment of commissioning across 
health and adult social care will be implemented and what the impact on the 
social care sector may be. The regulation of commissioning needs more 
attention as we move towards legislation on regulation. 
 
1.20 The ‘no-change’ option adopted for Monitor must be challenged. As 
mentioned above, its role should be as a ‘receiver’ for failing Foundation 
Trusts, not as an economic or competition regulator. 
 
1.22 Conflicting requirements of the bodies listed in 1.22 and other statutory 
requirements need attention. The increasing impact of EU Regulations and 
Directives should also be noted. The respective roles of these bodies- 
especially the NPSA and Health and Safety Executive - need to be 
considered carefully, alongside the new role for the proposed Regulator. The 
HSE in particular has taken an aggressive and punitive approach, taking legal 
action against leading providers, rather than adopting a risk-based approach. 
 
 There may be scope for a statutory duty of co-operation between the 
proposed Regulator and other bodies. There may also be an argument for a 
‘gatekeeper’ function for one regulatory body to take the lead in dealing with 
providers, in a specific sector. We welcome the review of the Concordat 
between the regulators. 
 
1.27 As noted above, these principles now have statutory force in the Legislative 
and Regulatory Reform Act 2006. There should also be a right of appeal for 
providers against assessments if they are unfair or inconsistent. 
 
1.30 The document is still fairly focused on health and does not make much 
reference to the useful analogies with other sectors such as communications. 
As the independent report observed, regulation in that sector focused on 
introducing competition. There is a need to inject more competition into the 
health sector. 
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
5
   
1.32 We would particularly agree with the first and third bullet points- that 
regulation should encourage self-assessment, and take account of overall 
value for money. 
 
1.33 The diverging and different regimes for regulation in the four countries of the 
UK are imposing further costs and burdens on providers which operate in all 
four. The issue of mixing economic and quality regulation in one organisation 
is essential to the debate. Lessons from other countries would be particularly 
valuable here. We feel that independent assessment of commissioners is 
vital. The issue of ensuring the right information is available to individuals and 
commissioners is also crucial. 
 
2.1 One of the biggest incentives for excellent standards of care may be to pay a 
fair price for that care. This is currently a major problem in social care, where 
there is no fixed tariff for fees. But financial incentives apply to all types of 
health and social care provider and form part of any economic analysis of the 
system. 
 
2.2 National minimum standards are already subject to some local interpretation 
by inspectors and local health and social care authorities. We believe there 
should be a short but firm list of national standards, focusing on principles for 
quality and safety, rather than detailed requirements. The current statutory 
National Minimum Standards constrain innovation in both health and social 
care. In social care, the point about attracting additional resources is also 
relevant as Authorities in fact cut the overall fee per resident on the basis of 
bulk buying, when a care home increases its occupancy. There is no 
equivalent to PbR and so these anomalies will become starker as the new 
Regulator comes into being. 
 
2.4 Under ‘monopoly power’, the point about ‘monopsony’ is also relevant. Local 
health and social care authorities do exercise monopsony power, by 
withdrawing contracts unilaterally or refusing to set realistic prices. For 
example, one PCT has cut independent providers from its Choose and Book 
list, and a Local Authority has proposed care homes fees which cut the price 
in real terms, without consultation. There are currently no effective routes for 
appeal against these misuses of monopsony power. 
 
 As asymmetric information is widely quoted as a reason for restricting the 
market in health care, it deserves more attention. A strong role in providing 
information to overcome this problem is required. However, information 
requirements should not breach commercial confidence. 
 
3
2.8 Lessons from other countries: the independent background report is helpful 
but we would include the drive towards patient safety and quality 
improvement in the USA, such as work undertaken by the Institute for Health 
Improvement, in this list. Terminology is important: accreditation in Australia 
and other countries is a useful process for assuring basic standards in 
providers. ‘Registration’ and ‘licensing’ may cover more or less rigorous 
processes of evaluation of providers. Independent providers in the UK are 
already registered and can effectively have their license to operate removed. 
                                                 
3
 The Future of Health and Adult Social Care Regulation 23 November 2006 
http://www.dh.gov.uk/PublicationsAndStatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/PublicationsPolicyAndG
uidanceArticle/fs/en?CONTENT_ID=4140889&chk=oZ%2Be8y 
 
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
6
  Whether and how these requirements will apply to NHS and Local Authority-
managed providers is at the heart of arguments about the new regulatory 
system. We incidentally note the prominence of stronger commissioners in 
other countries.  
 
 We also note the comment in the report that ‘most countries use independent 
experts in setting the tariff..’ Indeed, the Netherlands has an independent 
Board of Healthcare Tariffs. The discussion on page 28 of the independent 
report about the merits of outsourcing the setting of the tariff is useful.  
 
4.10 It is not clear why an appeal function is not necessary in social care. 
 
4.12 CSCI has made a powerful impact in favour of social care and has sought to 
drive up standards. There is some concern that their merger with the 
Healthcare Commission will dilute the focus on social care.  However, CSCI 
in its current form does not set relevant benchmarks which care homes can 
use to compare their performance and strive to improve on.  An integrated 
body must make it a priority to design appropriate means for benchmarking. 
 
4.19 We need more clarity on what information would be collected locally. It would 
be helpful if it was focused on outcomes and resident satisfaction as opposed 
to detailed metrics.  This would be consistent with the principles outlined in 
1.28. Information requirements should not breach commercial confidence. 
 
4.21 We support the negotiation of prices for care locally rather than having a 
national tariff, as this is consistent with the achievement of the objectives set 
out at 1.25 and 4.10. However, a Regulator needs to ensure that quality is not 
compromised by Authorities setting unrealistically low fees. For 2007-08, 
some Authorities are already proposing real-terms cuts in fees. This is 
inconsistent with the drive improve standards for residents and to give staff 
better employment conditions and training. 
 
5.5 Information and performance assessment: price information is commercially 
sensitive and so we would not support its publication. 
 
5.17 There is scope for looking at a national model contract for social care so as to 
cut down the transaction costs of rewriting contracts with each Local 
Authority. 
 
 
4. Responses to consultation questions 
 
 
Question 1 
 
The rapid technological changes which are taking place in health care are not fully 
reflected in the consultation document. The current system is based on inspecting 
premises – mainly hospitals and care homes- but a future system needs to avoid 
ossifying services which break down barriers between primary and secondary care. 
Public health also suffers as it loses priority to healthcare services because they 
must meet statutory standards. 
 
The new system needs to reflect the importance of preventive and public health 
services by setting outcome standards for these services. It also needs to cover GP 
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
7
  and primary care providers consistently; at present, GP practices are not regulated 
but private GPs are. 
 
Question 2 
 
The benefits of choice and competition can only be achieved with a light-touch 
regulatory system. But anti-competitive behaviour by NHS bodies such as recent 
awards of contracts without going out to tender must be constrained. Anti-competitive 
government action like subsidies to NHS organisations must also be restrained. The 
OFT is in a good position to do so, along the lines suggested on page 28 of the 
independent report already cited. 
 
 
Question 3 
 
Registration should focus on the organisations responsible for care and on assuring 
that those organisations have risk management in place, rather than just counting 
buildings. This will allow for the new Regulator to respond to innovations in service 
delivery. 
 
Question 4 
 
It is fundamental that all types of provider should meet the same requirements for 
registration. The practical limits to enforcing accreditation on NHS and Local 
Authority providers are recognised. This means that the basic listing or registration of 
provider organisations must be separated from quality assurance. 
 
In social care, will people only be able to spend Individual Budgets with registered 
providers? Will PCTs only be able to contract with registered providers?  
 
Question 5 
 
The forthcoming Lyons Review on the role of local government will also be relevant. 
The ability of local authorities to stifle competition and undermine the necessary 
provision of social care in their area should be restrained. Local Authorities need to 
see their role as promoting an effective market for social care. 
 
Question 6 
 
As for Question 4, common requirements for all types of provider are needed. 
 
Before considering the amalgamation of two large independent bodies, it must be 
ensured that each of those bodies is capable of covering its own immediate scope of 
regulation.  This comment particularly refers to the lack of Healthcare Commission 
regulation of cosmetic premises that may be performing invasive (e.g. Botox) 
procedures, with no safety assurance.  
 
It is imperative to consider the Care & Social sector in Connecting for Health agenda, 
and what role the new regulatory body will play in ensuring both its integration and 
the quality of evidence it submits. 
 
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
8
   
Consultation process 
 
 
BUPA has very much appreciated the Department’s approach to involving providers 
in this consultation process and in view of the complexity and importance of the 
issues, urges the Government to maintain a broad consultative approach to the 
following stages. It would be unfortunate to rush into legislation without first ensuring 
a lasting settlement on health and social care regulation. 
 
 
 
Duncan Innes  
Public Affairs Manager 
BUPA 
 
February 2007 
BUPA consultation response February 2007 innesd@bupa.com 
9
BUPA’s response to the consultation document on Regulation

title: Microsoft Word - AHM-2003-KON.doc
text:
Microsoft Word - AHM-2003-KON.docTHE METADATA MODEL OF THE NERC DATAGRID 
1 3 2 1, 3
Kevin O'Neill , Ray Cramer , Marta Gutierrez , Kerstin Kleese van Dam Siva Kondapalli , 
2 2 3 1
Susan Latham , Bryan Lawrence , Roy Lowry , Andrew Woolf  
1
CCLRC e-Science Centre 
2
British Atmospheric Data Centre 
3
British Oceanographic Data Centre 
Abstract 
The Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) DataGrid (NDG) aims to provide a framework for 
the discovery and use of data needed in NERC research. To support this, the NDG has developed a 
metadata and data model. The data model is directly concerned with the representation and use of the 
data, with the metadata model covering the discovery and higher-level considerations.  
The metadata model has started by considering the data holdings of the BADC and BODC, but will be 
extended as data from new disciplines is incorporated. To provide a framework for this extension, five 
distinct metadata objects have been identified as core to the NDG, providing the ability to support basic 
relationships between these core classes, while using sub-classing to provide specialisations where 
required. 
The schema will link with ontology systems, and will provide ways to express security policies, once 
these are established. 
Keywords: Metadata, ISO19115, OGC, TC211, NDG 
1. INTRODUCTION 
NERC has a very wide range of data 
• Allow discovery and access of data 
holdings, held in technologies from flat without having to have a priori 
files to relational databases. These holdings

FARMINGTON FELLOWSHIP REPORT 
 
SUSAN J MOORE                                MARCH 2006 
 
Teaching ‘Media’ through Concepts   
 
My intention in gaining a ‘Fellowship’ was to develop something practical 
which could be used by me and the R.E. department. I had already gained 
a ‘Best Practice’ Award and developed some units of work based on 
‘Thinking Skills’. I was interested in developing teaching through 
‘concepts’ and decided to link this in with a teaching unit on ‘Media’. 
 
The concept I chose to use was ‘morality’. I looked for parallel 
experiences which the students could identify with and decided to use 
Reality TV., advertising, music lyrics and ‘Soaps’. I then chose to relate all 
of this to religious faiths and ethical values. 
 
I was interested in researching how the media presents society and 
people in society; why there has been a boom in Reality TV and why we 
have become ‘fixated’ with ‘celebrities’. 
 
During my research time I took a school party to Auschwitz-Birkenau and 
can only describe it as the ‘most profound’ experience I have 
encountered. I was bothered by what I saw and experienced there, and 
the kind of senseless materialism and projection of how we look and 
behave that we as a society have become fixated with. Somehow it 
doesn’t fit in with what happened in Poland only 60 years ago. 
 
I am including examples of lessons which can be used for delivering 
‘Media’. They include different ideas for teaching and learning, starter 
activities and assessment for learning. The majority have been tried and 
tested with Year 11 students. Some of their feedback was to do with ‘Big 
Brother’ and included quotes such as: - ‘people desire fame for money 
because that’s what life is all about.’, ‘There are two extremes of talent – 
surgeons who are highly valued because they save lives, and the fact that 
it has become the norm to be a celebrity by having big boobs (you don’t 
need talent for that!) 
 
As a result of this research I watched many hours of R.T. and read many 
Celebrity magazines and magazines aimed at young men and young women. 
There are 176 RT programmes planned for 2006 and there are 8 ‘weeklies’ published which focus on TV ‘soap’ stars and their intimate lives. 
There are two types of celebrities – those that ‘use’ the media e.g. Simon 
Cowell, Jade Goody; and those that are ‘used’ by the media e.g. Kate Moss 
and Jodie Marsh. 
 
In conclusion there are many questions that have been unanswered for me 
but have been used as a basis for discussion in class. 
• Why has ‘Little Britain’ become so popular when it portrays British 
society as ‘idle’, ‘immoral’,’ antisocial’ etc..? 
• Is RT a form of escapism because our lives are so mundane and 
boring? 
• Why are people so desperate for fame and are so willing to be 
patronised and insulted on TV? 
• Is the media at fault because it bombards us with sex, glamour, 
money and fame? (Simon Cowell recently announced that he wanted 
a pay rise because £4.7 million wasn’t enough.) 
• What kind of society have we become when young people have ‘role 
models’ who are famous for being uneducated e.g. Jade Goody who 
is now worth £3.5 million. 
 
ZOO Magazine recently published this advert – ‘Win a boob job for 
your girlfriend, to transform her into a happier, more generous, 
intelligent, spiritual interesting person than she is today.’ 
 
Aristotle said that the aim of life was ‘happiness’. This could be 
achieved through human excellence of qualities of character and 
qualities of mind. Does RT, celebrities, money, glamour or fame bring 
any of these about? 
 
 SJM

title: Environment Agency - Painting and Degreasing
text:
Environment Agency - Painting and DegreasingEnvironment Agency - text only view
Skip direct to site navigation

		 
		
		
Painting and Degreasing



        
  		Mandatory Requirements

	If your facility uses more than 5 tonnes of organic solvent per year in a coating process, then you must contact the Local Authority in your area and apply for a permit to operate a prescribed process.  In Scotland, please contact your local SEPA office.


  			Local Air Pollution Control (LAPC) and Local Air Pollution Prevention and Control (LAPPC)

		


        
  			You must not use CFCs, HCFCs, 1,1,1 trichloroethane, bromochloromethane (CBM) or carbon tetrachloride for any degreasing or solvent application.  


  			Ozone depleting substances

		


        
  			If your plant has the capacity to use more than 150 kg per hour or more than 200 tonnes per year of organic solvents for coating processes, you should already have a permit under Part A (A(2) in England and Wales) of the Pollution Prevention and Control Regulations. 
In Northern Ireland if you use more than 400 tonnes of solid coating per year you should already hold a Part B authorisation from Industrial Pollution Radiochemical Inspectorate (IPRI).  You will automatically be transferred to the new PPC regime on 1st April 2008.  


  			Pollution Prevention and Control permits

		


        
  			If your facility carries out a powder coating process which uses more than 20 tonnes of solid coating per year, you will require a Part B or in Northern Ireland a Part C permit under the Pollution Prevention and Control (PPC) Regulations to operate a prescribed process.  
In Northern Ireland you may still hold a Local Air Pollution Control (LAPC) authorisation issued by your Local Authority and will automatically be transferred to the new PPC regime on 1st April 2006.
In England and Wales, the Local Authority issues Part B PPC permits.  You should already have applied for a permit under PPC as you will need an approved permit to operate from April 1st 2004.
In Scotland, you may still hold a Local Air Pollution Control (LAPC) authorisation. In most cases, SEPA will issue a new Part B PPC permit when your old LAPC authorisation is renewed at its normal 4 yearly interval. 


  			Local Air Pollution Control (LAPC) and Local Air Pollution Prevention and Control (LAPPC)

		

	Water in most paint booths is recirculated and disposed of as a separate waste.  However, if your spray shop discharges to sewer then you will need a trade effluent discharge consent from or trade effluent agreement with your local Water Company (in England and Wales), Scottish Water (Scotland) or the Water Service (Northern Ireland).  Make sure you follow the detailed instructions in the water section further below in this guide. 


Good Practice

	Storage containers and day tanks should be constructed of suitable materials.  Organic liquids are typically held in a metal tank, water-based liquids in polypropylene.  



	Carry out regular checks of process chemical storage areas to identify leaks or changes in practices e.g. unaccounted for new chemicals used in processes or anomalies in usage such as high consumption figures.



	Envirowise has produced several publications on managing and reducing solvent consumption.  These include:
- Cost-effective Solvent Management (GG013)
- Good Housekeeping Measures for Solvents (GG028)
- Cost-effective Reduction of Fugitive Solvent Emissions (GG071)
- Reduce Costs by Tracking Solvents (GG114)
- Stepping Ahead with Solvent Management (GC031)
- Profiting from Computer-based Solvent Management (GC108).

title: Welfare Reform on the Web (June 1999): Welfare Spending - UK
text:
Welfare Reform on the Web (June 1999): Welfare Spending - UK


	
	
		 
	

	
	
		

		

	
	
	Home > Welfare Reform > Issue number 2 > Welfare Spending - UK

	
            
	  
 
       Welfare Reform on the Web (June 1999): Welfare Spending - UK

       
       

BROWN DULLS THE PAIN OF SOCIAL ENGINEERING


R. Shrimsley

Daily Telegraph, March 11th 1999, p. 5


Argues that Gordon Brown is basically a tax-and-spend Chancellor whose
skill has been to hide the tax while emphasising the spend. Those on middle
and upper incomes have been deprived of mortgage tax relief and married
couples tax allowances; their pensions have been raided and their cars
further taxed. The money has been redirected from couples to parents and
from motorists to pensioners in accordance with Brown's sense of social
justice. Taxes levied on motorists will be given to pensioners; upper rate
taxpayers will pay more in national insurance contributions to help finance
family tax credits fro the less well-off.


BUDGET 1999


Key points of the budget from a welfare reform viewpoint are: 

	 a new 10p starting rate of income tax and basic rate tax cut to 22p.;
	married couples tax allowance scrapped and replaced by children's tax credit 
    worth up to ?416 per year;
	 child benefit raised to ?15 per week for the first child and ?10 
    for the second;
	Winter allowance for pensioners up from ?20 to ?100;
	minimum income guarantee for pensioners giving couples ?120 per week 
    and single people ?78; 
	 no national insurance contribution on first ?87 of weekly earnings 
    from 2001, and no contribution over ?575 a week. 


Guardian, March 10th 1999, p. 13-20; Independent Budget Review, 10th
March 1999, 24 p; Times, March 10th 1999, p. 9-20; Financial Times, 10th
March 1999, p. 1-29; Daily Telegraph Budget 99, 8 p.


THE CHANCELLOR WHO PRETENDS TO LOVE LOW TAX


R. Preston

Financial Times, March 10th 1999, p. 4.


Characterises Gordon Brown as a chancellor who pretended to love low
taxes while in fact preserving Labours traditional values. Help in the
budget is targeted on the poor at the expense of the rich through the reconstruction
of employees national insurance contributions and the replacement of the
married couples tax allowance with the children's tax credit.


THE COMPREHENSIVE SPENDING REVIEW


A. Britton

Crucible, Jan-Mar 1999, p. 31-39.


Presents a critique, from a Christian viewpoint, of the rhetoric of
the Comprehensive Spending Review, covering the level of spending and its
affordability, the selection of priorities within the total, welfare and
social security and the management of spending.


FRIEND TO WORKING RICH AND POOR


P. Stephens

Financial Times, March 10th 1999, p. 13.


Judges the budget to be redistributive, shifting a modest amount of
money from the higher paid to those at the bottom of the scale. Thus the
new family tax credit is paid for by increased National Insurance contributions
for those near the top of the income scale. The main beneficiaries, however,
are those able and willing to work. The toughened conditions attached to
the New Deal provide the stick while a plethora of tax incentives and credits
provide the carrot. The poor are to be given opportunity and decent income,
but they must be willing to work for it.


MIDDLE CLASSES AVOID THE PAIN OF REDISTRIBUTION


N. Timmins

Financial Times, March 10th 1999, p. 6.


Gains for those in low paid work, much more money for families with
children, and help for the least well-off are key features of a distinctly
redistributive budget. But while the poor will gain at the expense of the
better off, the chancellor's decision to boost purchasing power by ?6
bn over the next three years means it is being done with relatively little
pain for the middle classes.

					Youth Opportunity Fund Youth Capital Fund end of Year Report now published
30.Jul.2007The government has published a review of the first year of the youth opportunity and youth capital funds. It found that the funds were successfully set up across all local authorities and over 650,000 young people participated as decision-makers, project leaders or beneficiaries in the programme.
This report reviews the first year of the youth opportunity and youth capital funds. The government has set up these funds to give young people the opportunity to become actively involved in funding decisions for activities and facilities in their neighbourhood.
It found that the funds were successfully set up across all local authorities by the mid year point. Over 650,000 young people participated as decision-makers, project leaders or beneficiaries in the programme in the first year. A total of 12,226 projects were funded. The reports gives case studies and sets out areas for improvement in the second year. 
Read the reports in full >>
Visit the YCF YOF website >>

									The notification process

				
						
				
					Last modified date:
				

				
					8 February 2007
				

		


				

		Under the Community Care Act, hospitals must notify social services each time they anticipate a patient will need community care on discharge. They must also notify social services of proposed discharge dates, to ensure both parties are clear about when the reimbursement period will start.

								

											
						Model Notification: planning for the implementation of reimbursement and improving hospital discharge practice
	Notification Flowchart
	Example notification system - model notifications based on faxes
	Reimbursement - the timing of issuing notices - This document sets out the timing around issuing assessment and discharge notifications and gives examples of when reimbursement charging can start following the issue of notices




			



			
						Download Model Notification (PDF, 15K)
	Download Notification Flowchart (PDF, 43K)
	Download Example notification system (PDF, 20K)
	Download Reimbursement - the timing of issuing notices (PDF, 149K)

  SPEECH

Thursday April 7, 2005


  

  



Howard: The issues that matter to hard working Britons


		
			

		
		 
			
			
		
		
		
        
		
		
		

		
			Speech launching election campaign in the South, in Winchester

		
		"The choice before voters on May the fifth is very clear.  



They can either reward Mr. Blair for eight years of broken promises and vote for another five years of talk.  



Or they can vote Conservative, to support a party that's taken a stand and is committed to action on the issues that matter to hard working Britons.



Conservatives will restore discipline in our classrooms by giving head teachers control over their schools.  



We will clean up our hospitals by giving matrons the power to close wards that are infected with MRSA.  



We will cut crime by each year putting 5000 more police officers - real police officers - on our streets and introducing tougher sentences for burglars and drug dealers.



We will reduce immigration by setting an annual limit on the number of people who can come and settle in Britain.



And we will reward hardworking Britons by giving them value for money and lower taxes.



People work hard for their money and they deserve to keep more of it.



Mr. Blair promised that he had no plans to increase tax at all.  



But he has put taxes up 66 times - mostly by stealth.



And it's hurting.



According to the independent Institute for fiscal studies average incomes have started to fall for the first time in ten years.  



It's not the rich getting soaked.



It is normal, hard working families trying to make ends meet.



And if Mr. Blair gets in again ��� taxes will go up again.



Rarely in the history of politics has a government spent so much, taxed so much and achieved so little.



People work hard, they pay their taxes and they deserve value for their money. 



But today, families are paying an average of ��5,000 in extra tax a year - and what have they got to show for it? 



Everyone knows there is no such thing as a free lunch. 



With Mr Blair you pay for lunch ��� and it never seems to turn up.



Britain cannot carry on indefinitely spending more than it is earning without higher taxes or higher interest rates. 



If we are to secure our future economic prosperity, government must once again start to live within its means.



There are two Britains today: private sector Britain, where people are working harder just to stand still, struggling just to make ends meet. 



And bureaucratic Britain, where money is no object, you spend what you like, you employ who you like.

 

For every job the private sector lost last year, the public sector took on almost two more. Britain cannot carry on like this without storing up huge problems for the future. 



You know a country is living on borrowed time when government is the fastest growing industry in town.



So we have a plan to get a grip on government spending. 



That's why a Conservative government will cut waste.



There'll be 20 per cent fewer MPs, and 20 per cent fewer government ministers. 



Over 160 quangos will disappear. 



235,000 bureaucratic posts will go. 



We'll scrap the New Deal. 



There'll be no new Supreme Court.



And as for those unelected, unaccountable regional assemblies, the playthings of John Prescott, we'll get rid of them too.



Yes, these decisions are tough - but they are right. 



Right because they'll get resources to the front line - to our schools and hospitals - giving taxpayers value for their money.



Right because they'll help pay of debt and avoid Mr. Blair's tax rises.



And right because they'll enable a Conservative to lower taxes.  



I believe that families are better at spending their hard earned cash than any politician.



That is why Conservatives will cut taxes.

 

The hardest hit by Labour's stealth taxes have been the older generation.



If you want to know about a family, look at how they treat their older relatives. 



And if you want to know about a country, look at how it cares for its older generation. 



How a country treats the older generation is a test of its values. 



Many served our country in her greatest hour of need, fighting for liberty, freedom and Britain's independence for future generations. 



We must never forget the contribution they have made - and continue to make to our communities. 



But in Britain today too many pensioners are not shown the respect they deserve or given the dignity that is their due.



The older generation don't seem to feature in Mr Blair's New Britain. 



New Labour's Britain is a country where the older generation has been airbrushed out.



As Frank Field, Mr Blair's own former social security minister, has said Labour took one of the best pensions systems in Europe and turned into one of the worst.  



People who saved for their retirement suddenly found that the money they'd put aside simply wasn't there - that the value of their pensions had been destroyed by Mr Blair's stealth taxes.  



And Labour have forced nearly half all pensioners are onto means testing.  



Pensioners quite rightly resent means testing.  



It is at total odds with the values of the forgotten majority - the people who work hard, who take responsibility for themselves and save for their retirement.



Means testing is wrong.  



It penalises people for doing the right thing - saving for their retirement.  



It sends a clear signal to the younger generation: "Don't bother to save.  Spend whatever you can before you retire, because your future is one of dependency on the State".  



Means testing is humiliating - forcing pensioners to go cap in hand to the State for what they are due.  



And means testing is complicated.  That's why over one and a half million eligible pensioners don't even claim what they are owed.



I want our country to honour our senior citizens, cherish their wisdom and care for their needs - a country where they can live in security and with dignity, respected and protected. 



To those who have given so much, we must surely give what is their due.



I will increase the basic state pension in line with earnings, making pensioners up to ��11 a week better off after four years. 



By increasing the basic pension, we will free hundreds of thousands pensioners from the tyranny of means tested benefits - restoring their dignity, independence and self-respect. 



I will give every home where the adults are sixty five and over a fifty per cent Council Tax discount up to a maximum of ��500.  This will ensure that Council Tax bills for five million pensioners are cut.



Taken together these proposals will mean that pensioner households will be up to ��1,000 a year better off - it's a thousand pounds.   



And I will stop the disgrace of elderly people being forced to sell their homes, saying goodbye forever to their independence, to pay for their residential care.  



It's important that government rewards people who work hard and have contributed to our society.



And it's important too that government upholds the law.



Some people say I shouldn't talk about difficult issues like the abuse of our asylum system and those travellers who stick two fingers up to the law. 



But we cannot make Britain a better place if we sweep difficult issues under the carpet. 



Everyone knows you won't fix a problem if you aren't even prepared to discuss it.  



I'm not prepared to appease special interest groups because I believe passionately in fair play.  



We are all British and we should all have to play by the same rules. 



Nor will I be distracted from doing what I believe is best for Britain by the smirking politics of Mr Blair or the woolly thinking of the Liberal Democrats. 



So on each of these issues - on rewarding those who work hard and have contributed to our country, on schools, on hospitals, on crime and on immigration - we have a detailed, published Timetable for Action so you can hold us to account.  



Look for this commitment in your paper, check it on the net, put it up on your fridge door - hold me to it.  



And beware yet another election where Mr Blair says one thing to get your vote on polling day and does something quite different afterwards.



Mr. Blair is already secretly grinning about the prospect of his third victory.  



Imagine five more years of him.



Well you don't have to settle for it.  



If you're thinking what we're thinking, it's time for urgent action on the things that really matter:  



-                     Reward for hardworking Britons;



-                     School discipline;



-                     Cleaner hospitals;



-                     More police; and



-                     Controlled immigration.



So I say again, the choice before voters on May the fifth is very clear.  



They can either reward Mr. Blair for eight years of broken promises and vote for another five years of talk.  



Or they can vote Conservative, to support a party that's taken a stand and is committed to action on the issues that matter to hard working Britons."









 Send to a friend





         

        
			
			  
			
			  
			
			  
			  
			
			
			
	        About Rt Hon Michael Howard QC MP ��

title: CYNGOR LLYFRAU CYMRU
text:
CYNGOR LLYFRAU CYMRUCyngor Llyfrau Cymru
Cynllun Gweithredol 2006/ 072
 
CYNNWYS 
 
 
 
 Tud 
 
1 Datganiad Strategol       3 
 
 
 
2 Natur y ddogfen        3

4 Beth fydd y Cyngor Llyfrau?n ei gyflawni yn 2006/07   7 
 
 
 
5 Pa adnoddau fydd ar gael 12

 1 Cyllideb 2006/07 15 
 
 2 Dadansoddiad o?r Costau 2006/07 16 
 
 3 Grantiau Cyhoeddi 2006/07 17 
 
 4 Adroddiad Kewley/Richardson:  Cynllun Gweithredu 18 
 
 5 Cynllun Adolygu Gwariant (SpREE) 21 
 
 3
 
1 Datganiad Strategol 
 
Bu?r blynyddoedd diwethaf yn gyfnod o drawsnewid yn hanes Cyngor Llyfrau 
Cymru wrth i?w gyfrifoldebau ehangu?n sylweddol yn sgil trosglwyddo 
cyfrifoldebau am gyhoeddi o Gyngor y Celfyddydau (2003) ac i Lywodraeth y 
Cynulliad gynyddu?r ddarpariaeth grantiau ar gyfer cyhoeddi yn y Gymraeg (er 
2002) a chyhoeddi yn Saesneg (er 2004).  Canlyniad hyn oll oedd cadarnhau r?l y 
Cyngor Llyfrau fel y sefydliad sy?n gyfrifol am gyfeiriad strategol maes cyhoeddi 
yng Nghymru, yn y Gymraeg a?r Saesneg. 
 
Buddsoddi mewn awduron, cryfhau isadeiledd y tai cyhoeddi a gwell marchnata 
yw conglfeini?r strategaeth ar gyfer datblygu?r diwydiant cyhoeddi yng Nghymru, 
ac mae?r cyllid ychwanegol a ddarparwyd gan Lywodraeth y Cynulliad wedi 
dechrau dwyn ffrwyth ar yr ochr Gymraeg ac mae arwyddion cychwynnol 
calonogol ar yr ochr Saesneg hefyd.  Er hynny, mae?n ddyddiau cynnar o ran 
datblygu?r ochr Saesneg ac fe fydd angen buddsoddi ychwanegol sylweddol dros 
nifer o flynyddoedd os yw Llywodraeth y Cynulliad am weld gweithredu 
adroddiad pellgyrhaeddol Pwyllgor Diwylliant y Cynulliad, Ysgrifennu Saesneg 
1
yng Nghymru.
 
Yn unol ??r Cynllun Corfforaethol 2005/06?2007/08, bydd y pwyslais dros y 
blynyddoedd nesaf yn parhau ar wella ansawdd llyfrau (trwy fuddsoddi mewn 
awduron a golygyddion) a rhoi mwy fyth o sylw i werthiant a marchnata.  Rhaid 
pwysleisio hefyd bod isadeiledd y prif dai cyhoeddi yn parhau?n fregus a bydd y 
Cyngor Llyfrau?n parhau i dynnu sylw at yr angen i gynorthwyo ymhellach y prif 
dai cyhoeddi i ddatblygu?n fusnesau deinamig, llwyddiannus a all ddod yn llai 
dibynnol ar arian cyhoeddus yn y pen draw. 
 
Y newid mwyaf ers llunio?r Cynllun Corfforaethol diwethaf yw ymddangosiad 
2
adroddiad Kewley a Richardson ar gynrychiolaeth masnach.  Mae?r adroddiad 
hwn, a gomisiynwyd gan y Cyngor Llyfrau, yn adroddiad strategol o bwys fydd 
yn cyfeirio ein hymdrechion ym maes gwerthiant a marchnata dros y blynyddoedd 
nesaf.  Mae llythyr cylch gwaith y Gweinidog i?r Cyngor yn cyfeirio?n benodol at 
hwn ac yn nodi?r angen i?r Cyngor Llyfrau ?weithio gyda?r diwydiant i sicrhau 
bod pawb yn y gadwyn gyflenwi yn mabwysiadu ac yn glynu wrth ddisgyblaethau 
ac arferion gweithredol DU-gyfan o ran cyhoeddi a dosbarthu.  Dylai?r Cyngor 
Llyfrau arwain y gwaith o sefydlu proffesiynoldeb o?r fath drwy?r diwydiant 
cyhoeddi yng Nghymru . . .? 
 
 
2 Natur y ddogfen 
 
Mae?r ddogfen hon yn nodi?r hyn y bydd y Cyngor Llyfrau?n ei gyflawni yn y 
flwyddyn ariannol Ebrill 2006 i Fawrth 2007 o fewn yr adnoddau ariannol sydd ar 
gael. 
 
Y mae hefyd yn dangos sut y bydd y Cyngor Llyfrau?n cyfrannu at amcanion 
Llywodraeth y Cynulliad yn y flwyddyn dan sylw. 
 
 
1  
Ysgrifennu Saesneg yng Nghymru: Adolygiad, Pwyllgor Diwylliant, y Gymraeg a Chwaraeon, Mawrth 2004 
2  
Adolygiad o Wasanaeth Cynrychiolaeth Masnach Cyngor Llyfrau Cymru, David Kewley/Paul Richardson,  
   Gorffennaf 2005 4
 
 
Ni fwriedir ailadrodd cynnwys y Cynllun Corfforaethol cyfredol (2005/06?2007/08), 
ond bydd atodiad i?r Cynllun Corfforaethol yn gosod allan yr anghenion ariannol ar 
gyfer 2007/08.  Cyfeirir at dudalennau perthnasol yn y Cynllun Corfforaethol. 
 
3 Pwrpas, Swyddogaethau  Craidd a Phrif Amcanion 
 
 3.1 Pwrpas y Cyngor yn ?l ei Gyfansoddiad yw: 
 
hybu, cefnogi a datblygu gwerthfawrogiad a diddordeb y cyhoedd mewn 
llenyddiaeth . . . [trwy] 
 
a) cefnogi a chynorthwyo awduron ac addaswyr drwy roi grantiau a 
thrwy ddulliau eraill 
 
b) cefnogi, hybu a chynorthwyo cynhyrchu a dosbarthu llyfrau a deunydd 
llenyddol ac artistig arall, ym mha ffurf bynnag y?u cofnodwyd (boed 
trwy ddulliau sy?n hysbys neu trwy ddulliau sydd hyd yn hyn yn 
anhysbys), yn Gymraeg neu?n ymwneud ? Chymru 
 
c) trefnu a chynnal arddangosfeydd o?r cyfryw lyfrau a deunydd arall 
 
ch) cefnogi a hybu cyhoeddi?r cyfryw lyfrau a deunydd arall yng Nghymru 
 
Mae llawer o waith y Cyngor yn ymwneud ? darparu gwasanaethau 
sylfaenol i?r fasnach gyhoeddi ac, yn anochel felly, nid cynlluniau tymor-byr 
mohonynt.  Am restr o swyddogaethau craidd a phrif amcanion y Cyngor, 
gweler Cynllun Corfforaethol 2005/06?2007/08, tt. 6?7. 
 
 
3.2 Amcanion Llywodraeth y Cynulliad 
 
 Mae?r Cynllun hwn yn dilyn cyfarwyddiadau Llythyr Cylch Gwaith y 
Gweinidog dros Ddiwylliant, y Gymraeg a Chwaraeon ar gyfer 2006/07. 
 
 Cyfeiria?r Llythyr Cylch Gwaith at nifer o ddogfennau sy?n manylu ar 
agenda strategol y Llywodraeth a phwysleisir yr angen i gynlluniau cyrff 
cyhoeddus gyfrannu at y weledigaeth gyfansawdd a amlinellir yn y 
dogfennau hyn.  Cyfeirir yn arbennig at: 
 
? Cymru: Gwlad Well 
sy?n manylu ar y blaenoriaethau sylfaenol, sef datblygu cynaliadwy, 
cyfiawnder cymdeithasol a chyfle cyfartal.  Nodir y canlyniadau 
allweddol sy?n flaenoriaeth: 
- swyddi a sgiliau gwell, a mwy ohonynt 
- gwella iechyd 
- datblygu cymunedau cryf a diogel 
 
 (Mae?r cyntaf a?r trydydd yn berthnasol iawn i?r Cyngor Llyfrau) 
 
? Iaith Pawb 
? Cymru Greadigol 5
 
? Adroddiad Gr ?p Gorchwyl a Gorffen Llywodraeth y Cynulliad ar 
Gyhoeddi 
? Creu?r Cysylltiadau a Cyflawni?r Cysylltiadau 
 
Mae?r Cyngor Llyfrau?n ymwybodol fod yn rhaid gweithio tuag at gyflawni 
prif amcanion y Llywodraeth.  Gweler y tabl a baratowyd fel rhan o?r 
Adolygiad ar Wariant (SpREE) (Atodiad 5). 
 
 
Amcanion eraill y Llywodraeth 
? Gweithio mewn Partneriaeth 
Bydd y Cyngor yn gweithio mewn partneriaeth ag ystod o gyrff, gan 
gynnwys y rhai y cyfeirir atynt yn y Llythyr Cylch Gwaith, sef yr Adran 
Addysg, Dysgu Gydol Oes a Sgiliau (ACCAC gynt), Cyngor y 
Celfyddydau a?r Academi, Bwrdd yr Iaith Gymraeg, y Cyngor Prydeinig 
a?r Asiantaeth Sgiliau Sylfaenol.  Mae gan y sefydliad gysylltiadau cryf 
??r sector gwirfoddol hefyd, yn enwedig yng nghyd-destun 
gweithgarwch Diwrnod y Llyfr. 
 
Mae?r Cyngor yn falch o?r cyfle i fod yn rhan o?r Bwrdd Diwylliant 
newydd a gadeirir gan y Gweinidog, ac i gyfrannu tuag at y broses o 
ddatblygu polis?au diwylliant gwell a mwy integredig.  Cydnabyddir 
hefyd bwysigrwydd them?u Creu?r Cysylltiadau yng nghyswllt 
diwygio?r sector cyhoeddus. 
 
Bydd y Cyngor hefyd yn cydweithio?n agos ? CyMAL a llyfrgelloedd 
cyhoeddus Cymru yn 2006/07, yn enwedig gyda golwg ar weithredu 
argymhellion Llywodraeth y Cynulliad yng nghyd-destun Ysgrifennu 
Saesneg yng Nghymru. 
 
Bydd y Cyngor yn cefnogi gweithredu Cynllun Gofodol Cymru a 
Chynllun Gweithredu Datblygu Cynaliadwy trwy: 
? ystyried anghenion plant, pobl ifainc a phobl h ?n wrth gefnogi a 
hyrwyddo deunydd darllen Cymraeg a Saesneg 
? cefnogi?r weledigaeth yn Iaith Pawb trwy hyrwyddo deunydd darllen 
Cymraeg ar gyfer cymdeithas fodern, ddwyieithog 
? cefnogi gwaith cyhoeddwyr a llyfrwerthwyr ledled Cymru sy?n 
cyfrannu at welliannau cymdeithasol ac economaidd yn eu 
hardaloedd 
 
Bydd y Cyngor yn cefnogi cyflwyno Strategaethau Cymunedol yr 
awdurdodau lleol trwy: 
? sicrhau cefnogaeth i weithgareddau cymunedol Diwrnod y Llyfr gan 
yr awdurdodau lleol 
? sicrhau cefnogaeth i gynlluniau cymunedol cyhoeddwyr, 
llyfrwerthwyr a llyfrgelloedd megis teithiau awduron a lansiadau 
llyfrau 
 
Bydd y Cyngor yn ymgysylltu ? Phartneriaethau Cymunedau?n Gyntaf, 
lle y bo?n briodol, i?w cynorthwyo wrth gyflwyno Cynlluniau 
Gweithredu Cymunedol.  Gwneir hyn trwy dargedu?r ardaloedd hyn yng 6
 
nghyswllt Diwrnod y Llyfr a chyllido gweithgarwch mewn 
cydweithrediad ??r awdurdodau addysg a hefyd yr awdurdodau llyfrgell. 
 
 
Partner Gweithredu yn 2006/07 
Yr Adran Addysg, Dysgu Gydol 
? Trafod dulliau o barhau?r 
Oes a Sgiliau cydweithio yng nghyswllt 
cynlluniau a weinyddid gynt gan

dramor

Sydyn / Quick Reads

Llyfrau Sgiliau Sylfaenol 
CyMAL:  Amgueddfeydd 
? Datblygu gwales/llyfrgell
