? Elfennau o ddatblygu 
darllenwyr 
Culturenet Cymru / Llyfrgell ? Trafod dyfodol y cynllun 
Genedlaethol Cymru 
?Llyfrau o?r Gorffennol?. 
Cymunedau?n Gyntaf 
? Targedu?r ardaloedd hyn yng 
nghyswllt Diwrnod y Llyfr a 
chyllido gweithgarwch mewn 
cydweithrediad ??r awdurdodau 
addysg a hefyd yr awdurdodau 
llyfrgell 
Sector Gwirfoddol 
? Sicrhau cefnogaeth deg elusen 
gofrestredig i weithgareddau 
Diwrnod y Llyfr 
? Targedu dau fudiad gwirfoddol i 
gefnogi Diwrnod y Llyfr ar lefel 
genedlaethol 7
 
 
Prif-ffrydio 
Bydd y Cyngor yn ymdrechu i brif-ffrydio nifer o egwyddorion sylfaenol 
a sefydlwyd gan Lywodraeth y Cynulliad. 
 
Egwyddor Gweithredu yn 2006/07 
Cyfle Cyfartal Cydymffurfio ? pholisi cyfle 
cyfartal y Cyngor.  Mynediad 
cyfartal o ran y gwasanaethau a 
gynigir.  Penodi aelodau i banelau?r 
Cyngor trwy broses o hysbysebu 
cyhoeddus.   
Datblygu cynaliadwy Mae gwaith y Cyngor yn 
anuniongyrchol yn cyfrannu at 
ddatblygu cynaliadwy, e.e. trwy 
ddatblygu sgiliau a chreu cyfleoedd 
ar gyfer cyflogaeth. 
Cyfiawnder cymdeithasol Trwy gynorthwyo i greu deunydd 
darllen o safon yn y Gymraeg a?r 
Saesneg.  Hefyd trwy weithgarwch 
sy?n hybu darllen a llythrennedd.  
Noder bod y cynllun Stori Sydyn a 
drefnir ar y cyd ??r Asiantaeth 
Sgiliau Sylfaenol yn 2006 yn 
targedu?n benodol egin-ddarllenwyr. 
Anabledd Cydymffurfio ? gofynion Deddf 
Gwahaniaethu ar Sail Anabledd. 
Hybu?r Iaith Gymraeg Eisoes wedi?i brif-ffrydio. 
 
 
? Cyhoeddusrwydd/Brandio 
Bydd y Cyngor yn cydymffurfio?n llawn ? gofynion Llywodraeth y 
Cynulliad ar fater brandio ac yn cydnabod nawdd Llywodraeth y 
Cynulliad mewn digwyddiadau a chyhoeddiadau yn unol ??r canllawiau 
yn y llythyr Cylch Gwaith. 
 
 
4 Beth fydd y Cyngor Llyfrau?n ei gyflawni yn 2006/07 
 
 4.1  Blaenoriaethau
Mae?r blaenoriaethau a restrir ar t.11 o?r Cynllun Corfforaethol yn sefyll.  
Bydd cynnydd ym mhob un o?r blaenoriaethau ond mae rhai datblygiadau 
allweddol yn ddibynnol ar gyllid ychwanegol, e.e. ym maes Ysgrifennu 
Saesneg yng Nghymru ac o ran gweithredu?r Strategaeth Farchnata Gyt?n. 
 
4.2 Rhestr weithgarwch
 gw. Cynllun Corfforaethol tt. 12?19 8
 
 Rhestrir y prif weithgarwch o dan y penawdau canlynol: 
  Darparu Gwybodaeth, Hybu a Marchnata 
  Darparu Gwasanaethau 
   Cefnogi Awduron 
  Grantiau Cyhoeddi 
  Cyllid a Rheolaeth 
 
4.3 Sylw arbennig
 Rhestrir isod y cynlluniau y tynnir sylw penodol atynt yn y Llythyr Cylch 
Gwaith ynghyd ? rhai cynlluniau eraill o blith y rhai a restrir yn 4.1 a 4.2 
uchod.  Adroddir am y rhain yn yr adroddiadau chwarterol i swyddogion 
Llywodraeth y Cynulliad. 
 
 1  Grantiau Cyhoeddi
 Mae?r gyllideb ar gyfer Grantiau Cyhoeddi bellach yn un swm, sef 
?2,268,000 ar gyfer 2006/07.  Am ddosbarthiad yn ?l iaith y 
cyhoeddiadau, gweler t. 17 (Atodiad 3). 
 
 
2 Grantiau i ddeunydd Cymraeg
 Yn ystod 2005/06 cwblhawyd y broses o integreiddio rhan Gymraeg y 
Grant Llenyddiaeth gyda?r Grant Cyhoeddi.  O 1 Ebrill 2006 ymlaen, 
un gronfa gylchgronau fydd yna, a bydd Cyhoeddiadau Barddas, a 
oedd yn arfer bod yn gwsmer refeniw o dan y Grant Llenyddiaeth, yn 
dod yn gyhoeddwr rhaglen/llenyddol. 
 
 Yn ystod 2006/07 bydd y Cyngor yn monitro?r sefyllfa i weld sut y 
mae?r drefn newydd yn gweithio.  Bydd hefyd yn asesu?r ymchwil 
farchnad a wnaed yn ystod 2003?2006. 
 
 Bydd y Grant yn cefnogi: 
? Isafswm o 215 o lyfrau 
? 16 cylchgrawn 
? Isafswm o ddeg o brif gomisiynau i awduron 
? Comisiynau i ddarlunwyr/ffotograffwyr ? isafswm o bedwar 
? Cefnogi swyddi golygyddol yn saith o?r prif dai cyhoeddi 
? Grantiau i siopau llyfrau annibynnol ? isafswm o 15 
? Cefnogi llyfrau llafar ar ffurf casetiau sain neu gryno-ddisgiau ? 
isafswm o saith 
? Dosbarthu cyllid marchnata (?75,000) ? gweler rhif 5 isod 
? Cynnal ymchwil farchnad 
 
 
3 Grantiau i ddeunydd Saesneg
 Bydd y Grant yn cefnogi: 
? Isafswm o 65 o lyfrau 
? 4 prif gylchgrawn 
? Isafswm o 15 o flaendaliadau i awduron 
? Isafswm o 25 o gynlluniau marchnata 
? Isafswm o 4 o deitlau yng nghyfres Library of Wales ? gweler isod. 
 9
 
 Y flaenoriaeth fydd parhau?r gwaith o integreiddio cynlluniau?r hen 
Grant Llenyddiaeth gyda?r arian ychwanegol (?250,000) a ddaeth yn 
sgil yr adroddiad ar Ysgrifennu Saesneg yng Nghymru.  Bydd y 
canlynol yn cael sylw: 
? Parhau i roi sylw i fater ariannu craidd ar gyfer isadeiledd wrth 
gyfuno?r grantiau refeniw a?r cynllun i gefnogi swyddi. 
? Datblygu ymhellach y drefn o weinyddu?r grantiau marchnata 
newydd gyda golwg ar fonitro llwyddiant a sicrhau gwerth-am-
arian. 
? Adnewyddu cytundeb yr hyrwyddwyr mewn perthynas ? llyfrau 
Saesneg a pharhau i fonitro llwyddiant y cynllun. 
? Monitro?r cydbwysedd rhwng cefnogi llyfrau newydd, poblogaidd 
(gyda chymorth yr arian ychwanegol) a pharhau i ddatblygu?r ochr 
lenyddol. 
 
 
4 Adolygiad Ysgrifennu Saesneg yng Nghymru
? Bydd y pwyslais yn 2006/07 ar gefnogi rhagor o deitlau poblogaidd 
a gofalu bod yr holl gynlluniau?n cyfrannu?n uniongyrchol ac yn 
anuniongyrchol tuag at gryfhau isadeiledd y prif dai cyhoeddi yng 
Nghymru yn ogystal ? bodloni gofynion y cynlluniau unigol. 
? Monitro ffigurau gwerthiant wrth i lyfrau a gefnogwyd gyda?r arian 
newydd (blaendaliadau i awduron a/neu grantiau marchnata) 
ddechrau ymddangos. 
? Llyfrgelloedd ? gweler 8 isod. 
? Gwobrau i?r Diwydiant Cyhoeddi 
Paratoi ar gyfer y gwobrau nesaf a ddyfernir yn 2007.  Rhoi 
ystyriaeth i?r angen am ehangu rhychwant y gwobrau. 
? Cyfres Library of Wales 
Cyhoeddi?r cnwd nesaf o lyfrau (4 ym mis Medi 2006) a chynnal y 
safonau;  pwyslais cynyddol ar farchnata.  Cytundeb newydd i?w 
ddyfarnu am y cyfnod Hydref 2006?Mawrth 2008. 
 
 
5 Strategaeth Farchnata Gyt?n
 Ni fydd modd mynd i?r afael yn llawn ? gweithredu?r strategaeth hon, a 
luniwyd gan holl sectorau?r diwydiant ar y cyd, heb gyllid ychwanegol.  
Yn y cyfamser, byddwn yn parhau i ariannu nifer cyfyngedig o 
gynlluniau ar raddfa fechan ar sail blaenoriaethau?r gweithgor, o fewn 
cyllideb y Grantiau Cyhoeddi: 
? Cefnogi ceisiadau gan gyhoeddwyr tuag at lansiadau llyfrau a 
sesiynau llofnodi gydag awduron 
? Darparu hyrwyddwyr allanol at ddefnydd cyhoeddwyr er mwyn 
cynyddu?r sylw i lyfrau yn y wasg ac ar y cyfryngau 
? Parhau gyda?r gwaith o greu a chynnal Warws Gwybodaeth ar 
gyfer y diwydiant, llyfrgelloedd etc. 
? Cymorth tuag at weinyddiaeth Cwlwm y Cyhoeddwyr 
? Hysbysebu generig 
 
6 Gwales.com
 Lansio rhyngwyneb newydd gwales.com a gwefan newydd, 
gwales/llyfrgell.  Archwilio ffyrdd o alluogi pob llyfrgell yng 10
 
Nghymru i ddefnyddio?r gwasanaeth i?r eithaf, o ran gwybodaeth ac 
archebu. 
 
 
7 Y Ganolfan Ddosbarthu
? Dechrau gweithredu system EDI i hwyluso cyfathrebu electronig. 
? Ystyried unrhyw argymhellion sy?n berthnasol i?r Ganolfan 
Ddosbarthu yn yr adolygiad ar gynrychiolaeth ? gweler 9 isod. 
 
 
8 Llyfrgelloedd
 Bydd lansio  gwales/llyfrgell yn ystod y flwyddyn yn golygu bod prif 
argymhelliad yr adroddiadau ar bwrcasu llyfrau Cymraeg a llyfrau 
Saesneg wedi?i weithredu.  Bydd rhestr graidd o lyfrau Saesneg o 
Gymru yn cael ei chreu gyda chymorth y llyfrgellwyr a CyMAL a 
bydd y rhestr hon yn cael ei rhoi ar y wefan er hwylustod i lyfrgelloedd 
ac er mwyn eu cynorthwyo i ddatblygu eu casgliadau. 
 
 Byddwn yn trafod gyda CyMAL ddatblygiadau pellach er budd 
llyfrgelloedd. 
 
 
9 Gwerthiant, Marchnata a Hyrwyddo
? Bydd gweithredu prif argymhellion adroddiad Kewley/Richardson

docs.description: This issue of Fuse looks at how simple actions can bring revolutionary results.  It only takes simple action to prevent river blindness.  Yet, the disease has blinded over 270,000 people and infected a further 18 million.  A revolution is needed.  We also explore how the revolution that Jesus brings to our own lives can revolutionise the way we see the world.

This issue of Fuse looks at how simple actions can bring revolutionary results.  It only takes simple action to prevent river blindness. Yet, the disease has blinded over 270,000 people and infected a further 18 million. A revolution is needed.  We also explore how the revolution that Jesus brings to our own lives can revolutionise the way we see the world.

						Northern Ireland: Amnesty Condemns Treatment of Asylum Seekers

						
							
								Amnesty International has condemned the treatment of asylum seekers in Northern Ireland, after a report from HM Chief Inspector of Prisons.
								Posted: 16 May 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Northern Ireland: Amnesty rejects tasers for P.S.N.I as John Reid proposes wider development

						
							
								On 16 May Amnesty International rejected the proposed deployment of Taser electro-shock weapons to the PSNI, as Home Secretary John Reid announced that more police in Britain are set to get the 50,000-volt devices.
								Posted: 16 May 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Amnesty Urges Release of  Aid workers in Somalia

						
							
								Amnesty International has called for the safe, immediate release of two aid workers from Northern Ireland and Kenya feared kidnapped in Somalia. 
 

								Posted: 10 May 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Amnesty Urges Action on QUB Corporate Sponsor Caterpillar 

						
							
								Amnesty International is urging Queen's University and its students at to bring pressure on Caterpillar Inc for their role in the destruction of Palestinian homes. 
								Posted: 8 May 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Northern Ireland: Primary schools take action on Darfur

						
							
								Primary schools across Northern Ireland are holding special human rights lessons to mark the fourth anniversary of the deadly conflict in Darfur.



								Posted: 29 Apr 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Cathedral Quarter To Host Amnesty International Protect The Human exhibition 

						
							
								A star-studded photo exhibition by human rights organisation Amnesty International is to go on show for the first time in Northern Ireland as part of the cathedral quarter Arts Festival 


								Posted: 25 Apr 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Amnesty Condemns Death Threats to Human Rights Defenders

						
							
								Amnesty International has condemned the recent death threats issued to the director of a local victims group in Northern Ireland.
								Posted: 16 Apr 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						NI: Alan Johnston abduction - Northern Ireland campaigners join Amnesty appeal, one month on

						
							
								Amnesty International supporters in Northern Ireland are sending 'Urgent Action' appeals on behalf of the abducted BBC television news reporter Alan Johnston, who is still missing in Gaza one month after being kidnapped by unidentified armed men.
								Posted: 12 Apr 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						NI: Amnesty welcomes Derry City Council vote to ban “torture flights” from airport

						
							
								Amnesty International has welcomed the vote by Derry City Council to adopt in principle a new 'anti-rendition' policy for use at the council-owned City of Derry Airport.
 

								Posted: 28 Mar 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						NI: City of Derry Airport urged to adopt 'anti-rendition' policy

						
							
								Amnesty International is urging Derry City Council to adopt a new 'anti-rendition' policy for use at the council-owned City of Derry Airport.
								Posted: 20 Mar 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						NI: Amnesty International welcomes appointment of Chair of Bill Of Rights Forum

						
							
								Amnesty International welcomes the appointment of leading Australian human rights lawyer, Chris Sidoti, as the independent Chair of the Bill of Rights Forum and calls for further steps by Government to help make Forum effective.
								Posted: 15 Mar 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Northern Ireland: Snow Patrol headline new human rights album

						
							
								Eagerly anticipated 'Instant Karma', a compilation CD of classic John Lennon songs recorded by an array of best-selling artists will be released by Warner Brothers in conjunction with Amnesty International on June 12th. The album will  include Northern Ireland's own Snow Patrol.
								Posted: 13 Mar 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						NI: Amnesty welcomes government decision to sign European Convention Against Trafficking

						
							
								Amnesty International Northern Ireland today (23 January 2007) welcomed the Prime Minister's announcement that the UK Government is to sign up to the European Convention Against Trafficking.
								Posted: 23 Jan 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						NI: Amnesty International response to Police Ombudsman report

						
							
								Amnesty responds today (22 January 2007) to a report from Police Ombudsman of Northern Ireland Nuala O'Loan on collusion between security forces and loyalist paramilitaries.
								Posted: 22 Jan 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Northern Ireland: Human rights prize awarded to Shankill Road primary school

						
							
								Pupils at Malvern Primary School, near Belfast's Shankill Road, will be presented today (15 January) with a hand-made 'friendship bench', their prize for winning a cross-border human rights art competition.
								Posted: 15 Jan 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						NI: Amnesty to mark five-year 'anniversary' of Guantánamo with Belfast demonstration

						
							
								Amnesty International Northern Ireland is to mark the five-year 'anniversary' of the first 'war on terror' detainees being transported to the US military prison at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba with a demonstration in Belfast.
								Posted: 9 Jan 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						Northern Ireland: Amnesty International concerned by launch of 'handbag sized' taser stun gun for US public

						
							
								Amnesty International has expressed concern at the recent decision by Taser International to launch a new electro-shock weapon for the US general public and has renewed its calls for an independent and comprehensive study into its use.
								Posted: 9 Jan 2007
							

						

					

				
					
						UK: Amnesty welcomes NI Bill of Rights Forum

						
							
								Amnesty International has welcomed the establishment by the Government of the Northern Ireland Bill of Rights Forum, which has its preliminary meeting today at Parliament Buildings, Stormont.
								Posted: 18 Dec 2006
							

						

					

				
					
						NI: Belfast Amnesty joins protests in more than 40 countries demanding protection for the people of Darfur

						
							
								A multi-faith vigil will be held for the people of Darfur on the steps of St Anne's Cathedral, Sunday 10th December at 12.15pm.
								Posted: 10 Dec 2006
							

						

					

				
					
						UK: NIO gets damning report card: just one out of ten for tackling violence against women

						
							
								Amnesty International, working as part of the End Violence Against Women Campaign, today launches a damning new report, Making the Grade 2.  This new report awards the Northern Ireland Office a score of just one out of ten for its policies and practices for tackling violence against women. The Government overall was awarded a mark of two out of ten.
								Posted: 6 Dec 2006

			Skip to content





Online repository opens

31 August  2007

The NERC online repository for research which opened in June now contains
  metadata or full text articles of over 600 documents and research papers. The
  Open Research Archive (NORA) stores outputs of NERC science. 

NORA project manager, James Swaffield said, "One of the aims is to raise awareness
  of the science NERC does and to share science outputs to improve collaboration
  and scientific impact."

Currently only NERC's research centre staff are able to deposit items into
  NORA but the team hope to extend access to all NERC grant holders in 2008.
  Research centre scientists are obliged to deposit papers if funding started
  after October 2006. Prior to this date, submissions are welcome but not mandatory.

The archive is fully accessible online and free to submit and browse.

NERC Press Office
Natural Environment Research Council
Polaris House, North Star Avenue
Swindon, SN2 1EU

Mob: 07917 086 369

back

						

					
				
Monday 19 February 2007 13:35			
	
				

				
				Big Lottery Fund (East)

				

										
				Lottery brings better play to East Cambs


				

					
					


 Children across East Cambridgeshire will get a variety of new play facilities and increased opportunities for play thanks to £200,000 of lottery funding announced today. 
  The Big Lottery Fund award, for the East Cambridgeshire District Council is part of a £12million play cash pot being shared among 32 local authorities across England that will use the money to deliver portfolios of projects that develop, create, improve and design innovative children's play facilities. The scheme is part of the Big Lottery Fund's £155million commitment to support children's play. 
  The East Cambridgeshire Better PLAY Project will transform play facilities at twelve sites across the district over three years. In the first year of this project the villages of Isleham and Stetchworth will receive funding for creative improvements to their play spaces to engage young people. 
  Also as part of the project, a Play and Physical Activity Co-ordinator will be employed to develop play activities across East Cambridgeshire, particularly in communities that lack suitable facilities or opportunities. 
  Finally, funding will also provide investment into play spaces for teenagers; an area that is often overlooked when designing play opportunities. 
  Cecilia Tredget, Deputy Chief Executive, said: "This lottery award is excellent news for children and young people in East Cambridgeshire. The funding will be a catalyst, not only for increasing play activities and opportunities but for the growth in local partnership working to create a long-term legacy for play in the district''. 
  "It is important we provide positive activities that engage young people of all ages particularly the hard to reach. The Better Play Project will target rural areas where young people are disadvantaged due to limited access to play facilities. We have established a Play Partnership that includes various partners across the district to ensure our play services meet the needs of local young people." 
  Sara Betsworth, Head of Region for the East of England, said: "This investment of lottery money will go a long way in bringing stimulating and challenging play to children and young people across East Cambridgeshire. In isolated or disadvantaged areas it's often difficult to access play facilities and equipment; this funding will ensure more families can enjoy better play for their children." 
  Further information: 
 Big Lottery Fund 
 Public Enquiries Line: 08454 102030 
 Textphone: 0845 6021 659 
 Full details of the Big Lottery Fund programmes and grant awards are available on: http://www.biglotteryfund.org.uk 
  Notes to Editors 
  * For more information about the East Cambridgeshire Better PLAY Project contact Phillip Turner, Senior Sports & Leisure Officer, East Cambridgeshire District Council on 01353 616382 or email phillip.turner@eastcambs.gov.uk. 
 * The Big Lottery Fund will support children's play with £155 million through: 
 - the £124 million Children's Play programme, with funds available to every local authority area in England; 
 - a separate £16 million Playful Ideas programme focussing on innovation; and 
 - a £15 million grant to the Children's Play Council, part of the National Children's Bureau, to fund England-wide development and support. 
 * Under the Children's Play programme, in deciding how best to allocate the available funds to each authority the Big Lottery Fund have allocated: 50 per cent of the funding on the basis of child population, and 50 per cent of the regional population living in the most deprived 20% of Super Output Areas included in the Index of Multiple Deprivation 2004. The minimum amount allocated to any local authority is £200,000. 
 * Under Playful Ideas registered charities; voluntary or community groups; charitable or not-for-profit companies; social enterprises; and town and parish councils can apply. However, other organisations, such as schools, can work in partnership on Playful Ideas projects. 
 * The Big Lottery Fund awarded a grant to the Children's Play Council a strategic alliance of organisations working to promote the importance of play and to stimulate better play opportunities. Play England - a project of the Children's Play Council - lead on this work by helping agencies to develop play strategies and apply for Children's Play funding. For further information please visit http://www.ncb.org.uk 
 * The Big Lottery Fund rolls out close to £2 million in lottery good cause money every 24 hours, which together with other Lottery distributors means that across the UK most people are within a few miles of a Lottery-funded project. 
  
 
  Client ref 07-02-37 
  GNN ref 144120P

title: Knowhere: Docklands, Greater London, Going Out, Clubs, Music Venues, Cinemas
text:
Knowhere: Docklands, Greater London, Going Out, Clubs, Music Venues, Cinemas

	
The Knowhere Guide

Going Out in Docklands, Greater London*

Docklands, Greater London Clubs, Music Venues, Cinemas


	* Important Note: all entries in the Knowhere Guide are the opinions of its users. see What is Knowhere for more info about the Guide.

	




Clubs (Dance Music) and Music Bars

	disco for over30,s

	There are none. This is sounding like a terrible area isn't it?



Live Music Venues

	Well London Arena but that is really Isle of Dogs. There are lots of pubs which have music on sometimes - The Barley Mow and Five Bells and Blade Bone in Limehouse, Scuzi at Canary Riverside, the Railway near Limehouse station to name a few. Pizza Express in Wapping has the usual Jazz stuff.



Cinemas

	UGC down east india quay

	UGC West India Quay for all your mainstream stuff and the odd interesting independent. The Space in Isle of Dogs for everything else on a dodgy video projector (but worth the 2ish quid entrance and the opportunity to eat food while you watch).










For a map of Docklands click here

What is Knowhere?


The Knowhere Guide started out as a list of places to skateboard in the UK. It is a compilation of (unedited) information and views supplied by users like yourself. It is not a conventional tourist guide!


In most cases, the information in each section has been submitted by more than one contributor 
(the credits at the bottom of the page list some, but not all, of the contributors) and some of it dates back to the 1970s.


We make no claims as to the accuracy of the information in the Guide - our only purpose is to provide a forum for users to share their knowledge and opinions. So please keep a large bag of salt handy and be prepared to read between the lines!


If you disagree with a comment, or information is out of date, please submit an update! The contributors come from all walks of life, and their opinions are bound to be subjective, so if your view isn't represented, please speak up and contribute to the balance of the Guide. See below in the 'Have Your Say' section for how to add your voice.


If we have helped you out or made you laugh you can buy us a pint.



 
Have Your Say...

The Knowhere Guide depends entirely on real users for information. Please feel free to join in. 
You can tell us more about Docklands. 
This is also the method to use if you want to correct some of the information already here. 
(But please remember you're not mailing the person who actually wrote whatever-it-is.) 


You can use the add an event form
to tell us about events happening in Docklands.


Or, if you'd just like to leave a message for other users of this site, take a look at The Knowhere Board (handy if you're just trying to get in touch with someone). 




Credits


All the information in the Knowhere Guide has been contributed by users over the years. No one person is responsible for it all and not all contributors will agree with all the opinions included. 

Parts of this information have been supplied by:
Ben Jefferys,robbie,vespadon@yahoo.com,Joanna Godden,dave,anna,mojo


Last updated: 2006-10-19




Mail our automatic mailback service at info@knowhere.co.uk for helpful information and further details of how to contact Knowhere. Thanks.

Knowhere regards your privacy with utmost importance. Read our privacy policy.




Knowhere is a member of the state51 conspiracy.

	Export Credits Guarantee Department

	


			
			
			
			
				
						



	
The ECGD works to benefit the country's economy, by helping UK exporters to win business and UK firms to invest overseas. We do this in a number of ways, but principally by providing support for export finance, credit insurance and overseas investment insurance. In 2001/2 we supported around �3bn of UK exports. 

We have offices in London and Cardiff and currently employ some 400 people in a variety of jobs. Candidates interested in a career with us can look forward to a challenging and highly rewarding working environment, in roles such as underwriting, finance, claims and post issue management work, product marketing, policy evolution, market assessment, corporate risk and administrative support.

title: Section 2
text:
Section 2Page  PAGE  2  of   NUMPAGES  1 

Section 2 Chapter 23

Page  PAGE  3  of   NUMPAGES  1 

	Section 2 Chapter 23






Section 2

Chapter 23

Regulatory accounts;

Analysis of turnover and operating income

 Section 2

Chapter 23

Regulatory accounts; Analysis of turnover and operating income

Commentary

This table analyses the components of turnover and other operating income. It is important that turnover is reported on a basis consistent with the Principal Statement. In particular, revenue raised by any rateable value element of the measured sewerage tariff is to be included in the measured turnover figures.


Turnover derived from large user customers for the full year should be shown separately on line 5 and excluded from line 1.


Turnover derived from third parties is required to be separately disclosed. The related costs are to be disclosed in tables 21 and 22.


Commentary should be provided on the calculation of the working capital adjustment.


No other specific guidance is given for the production of commentaries by the company, but significant movements over the last period should be noted.

 Column definitions:

Column 3 is the sum of columns 1, 2.

Column 6 is the sum of columns 4, 5.

References to columns 4, 5 and 6 may be assumed to apply, with the necessary changes, to columns 1, 2 and 3 (prior year).


Line definitions


1

Measured [column 4 - water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Measured water turnover


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All revenue derived from the sale of water at standard rates where all or some of the charges are based on measured quantities of volume. Exclude revenue from large users as defined in line 5 below.


Standard rates are tariffs, which are included in the Principal Statement.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO 11.01



1

Measured [column 5 – sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Measured sewerage turnover


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All revenue derived from the provision of sewerage services at standard rates where all or some of the charges are based on measured quantities of volume. Exclude revenue from large users as defined in line 5 below.


Standard rates are tariffs that are included in the Principal Statement. This includes revenue raised by any rateable value element of measured sewerage tariff.


Sewerage services includes sewage treatment and disposals, but excludes reception, treatment and disposal of trade effluent.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.22






 

2

Unmeasured [column 4 - water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Unmeasured water turnover


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All revenue derived from the sale of water other than on a measured basis. Including revenue from optional unmeasured water charges at standard rates e.g. hosepipes and swimming pools. Standard rates are tariffs that are included in the Principal Statement.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.10




2

Unmeasured [column 5 – sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Unmeasured sewerage service turnover


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All revenue derived from the provision of sewerage services at standard rates other than on a measured basis. Standard rates are tariffs that are included in the Principal Statement. This excludes revenue raised by any rateable value element of measured sewerage tariff.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.30




3

Trade effluent [column 5 – sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Trade effluent turnover


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All revenue derived from the reception, treatment and disposal of trade effluent at standard rates. Exclude revenue from large users as defined in line 5 below. Standard rates are tariffs that are included in the Principal Statement.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.40





4

Revenue grants [column 4 - water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Revenue grants - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All revenue grants received for the provision of water services.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.50




4

Revenue grants [column 5 – sewerage services ]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Revenue grants - sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All revenue grants received for the provision of sewerage services.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.55




5

Large user revenues [column 4 – water services ]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Large user revenues - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Revenue from all large user customers that are excluded from the tariff basket. 

			These are customers whose premises have, if the area of the relevant undertaker concerned is wholly or mainly in Wales, a requirement for not less than 250 Ml of water per year, or in all other cases a requirement for not less than 100 Ml of water per year. 


Processing rules:	Input field


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.75









5

Large user revenues [column 5 – sewerage services ]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Large user revenues – sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Revenue from all large user customers that are excluded from the tariff basket. These are customers whose premises have, if the area of the relevant undertaker is wholly or mainly in Wales, a requirement for not less than 250Ml of water per year, or in all other cases a requirement for not less than 100 Ml of water per year.  Include all revenue from large users that are excluded from the tariff basket, whether the revenue is from the provision of sewerage services or the reception, treatment and disposal of trade effluent.


Processing rules:	Input field


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.76


 

6

Other sources (excluding third parties) [column 4 – water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Other sources (excluding third parties) - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All other sources of turnover for water services, including non-tariff basket charges, rechargeable works, special agreements, compensation, contributions from developers (of a revenue nature) and Section 40 and 71 annual deficits, but excluding income from services provided for third parties.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	 BO11.60


 

6

Other sources (excluding third parties) [column 5 – sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Other sources (excluding third parties) - sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		All other sources of turnover for sewerage services, including non-tariff basket charges, rechargeable works, special agreements, compensation, contributions from developers (of a revenue nature) and Section 40 and 71 annual deficits, but excluding income from services provided for third parties.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.70



7

Third party services [column 4 – water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Third party services - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Revenue derived from third parties for the provision of water services for which costs are separately disclosed in table 21.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.91




7

Third party services [column 5 – sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Third party services - sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		The revenue derived from providing sewerage services to third parties for which costs are separately disclosed in table 22.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.92



 

8

Total turnover [column 4 - water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Total turnover - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Total appointed business revenue for water services.


Processing rules:	Calculated field: the sum of lines 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7.


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.81 










8 

Total turnover [column 5 – sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Total turnover - sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Total appointed business revenue for sewerage services.


Processing rules:	Calculated field: the sum of lines 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO11.82



 

9

Current cost profit or loss on sale of fixed assets [column 4 – water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Current cost profit or loss on sale of fixed assets - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Net current cost profit/loss on disposal of fixed assets relating to water services.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number for profits, negative if loss)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO29.92



 

9

Current cost profit or loss on sale of fixed assets [column 5 - sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Current cost profit or loss on sale of fixed assets - sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Net current cost profit/loss on disposal of fixed assets relating to sewerage services.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number for profits, negative if loss)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO29.94











 10

Exceptional items [column 4 – water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Exceptional items - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Exceptional items of an income nature are material net inflows which derive from events or transactions that fall within the ordinary activities of the company, and which need to be disclosed by virtue of their size or incidence if the financial statements are to give a true and fair view. This is consistent with paragraph 5 of FRS3 ‘Reporting Financial Performance’.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references	BR9.40




10

Exceptional items [column 5 – sewerage]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Exceptional items – sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Exceptional items of an income nature are material net inflows which derive from events or transactions that fall within the ordinary activities of the company, and which need to be disclosed by virtue of their size or incidence if the financial statements are to give a true and fair view. This is consistent with paragraph 5 of FRS3 ‘Reporting Financial Performance’.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number)


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references	BR9.45


 11
Other operating income [columns 1 & 4 – water services]
£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Other operating income – water services.


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Other operating income derived from operating activities for the water service (i.e. not classified as other income) but excluding exceptional items and profit/loss on disposal of fixed assets.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number).


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BR9.70


11
Other operating income [columns 2 & 5 – sewerage services]
£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Other operating income – sewerage services.


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Other operating income derived from operating activities for the sewerage service (i.e. not classified as other income) but excluding exceptional items and profit/loss on disposal of fixed assets.


Processing rules:	Input field (positive number).


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team.


Previous references:	BR9.71




12

Total operating income [column 4 – water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Current cost operating income - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Current cost profit on disposal of fixed assets related to water services plus exceptional income relating to water services.


Processing rules:	Calculated field: the sum of lines 9, 10 and 11.


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references: 	BO30.70




12

Total operating income [column 5 – sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Current cost operating income - sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Current cost profit on disposal of fixed assets relating to sewerage services plus exceptional income relating to sewerage services.


Processing rules:	Calculated field: the sum of lines 9, 10 and 11.


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO30.80








12

Operating income [column 6]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Total current cost operating income - water and sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		Current cost operating income includes current cost profit or loss on disposal of fixed assets and income from exceptional items. Exceptional items are defined in paragraph 5 of FRS3 ‘Reporting Financial Performance’.


Processing rules:	Calculated field: the sum of line 12, columns 4, 5.


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO30.90




13

Working capital adjustment [column 4 - water services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Working capital adjustment - water services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		An adjustment for the impact of general inflation on the real value of working capital to the business for water services.


Note:	A reduction in profit carries a negative sign.


Processing rules:	Input field


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO30.00




13

Working capital adjustment [column 5 – sewerage services]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Working capital adjustment - sewerage services


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		An adjustment for the impact of general inflation on the real value of working capital to the business for sewerage services.


Note:	A reduction in profit carries a negative sign


Processing rules:	Input field


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO30.50




13

Working capital adjustment [column 6 – total]

£m (3dp)


Full line title:		Working capital adjustment – total 


Primary Purpose:	Informing relative performance and efficiency assessments.


Definition:		The adjustment for the impact of general inflation on the real value of working capital to the business for both water and sewerage.


Processing rules:	Calculated field: the sum of line 13, columns 4, 5


Responsibility:		Regulatory Accounts and Business Affairs Team


Previous references:	BO30.60
 CHANGE CONTROL SHEET

CHAPTER 23



Issue/date

Description of change


2001/1.0 20/12/00
New guidance on turnover.

Line 1 – revision to definition on excluding revenue from large users.

New line 5 collects data on revenue from large users.

Old lines 5-12 renumbered 6-13.


2001/1.1

31/03/01
BoN references inserted for new lines.

Line 8 – calculation rules amended to take account of lines not used for water or sewerage service turnover totals and addition of Third Party Services (line 7).

Line 12 – revision to definition to correspond with table 20 line 3 and calculation rules.

Line 12 and line 13, column 6 - calculations revised.


2002/1.0

	Amendments to definitions for lines 3 and 5.

	Line 5 – sewerage services  collects data on revenue from large users.

title: Environment Agency - Energy Efficiency
text:
Environment Agency - Energy EfficiencyEnvironment Agency - text only view
Skip direct to site navigation

		 
		
		
Production, Processing and Preserving of Meat and Poultry 
Energy Efficiency

Guidelines



        
  		Food processing can be an energy intensive industry.  A Negotiated Agreement, made between your trade association (e.g. Food and Drink Federation - signatories to the UK umbrella agreement, there is no individual agreement with the NI Food and Drink Association, British Beer and Pub Association, Dairy Industry Association Ltd etc.) and the Government, may be available to your business.  Such Agreements enable signatories to claim a valuable 80% rebate on the Climate Change Levy, provided that binding targets for improving energy efficiency are met. 

For information on energy efficiency measures, contact your trade association or use the link below: 

  			Action Energy

		
	Defra - Climate change

		
	Energy efficiency

		
	Envirowise - Energy Links

		

This guidance is relevant to the following business areas:
Production, Processing and Preserving of Meat and Poultry  (current business area) | Agricultural Feed Manufacture | Fish and Shellfish Processing | General Food and Drink Processing | Grain Milling | Manufacture of Beverages | Manufacture of Breakfast Cereals | Manufacture of Dairy Products | Manufacture of Prepared Pet Foods | Manufacture of Starch and Starch Products | Vegetable Oil Extraction and Fat and Oil Refining Processes

IMPORTANT LEGAL NOTE

NetRegs contains simplified guidance based on complex and changing legislation, and does not constitute legal advice. Whilst we endeavour to keep it up to date, we cannot be held liable for errors and omissions; compliance with the law remains the user's responsibility. If you have concerns over compliance, you must seek professional advice, or contact your regulator or local authority.

INSIDE THE WHALE: Dispatches from within corporate leviathan Marrch 17th, 2006



home >> LATEST NEWS >> March 17, 2006







Its one of my favourite gags: Tonto and the lone Ranger find themselves surrounded by a band of angry, axe-waving Sioux.  ‘Well,’ says the Lone Ranger ‘looks like we’re done for, Tonto’.  Tonto gives him a blank look.  ‘What do you mean “we”, paleface?’





I am trying to control my we.  It’s tough, the meeting has been long and heated and now there’s we all over the place.  ‘We have to increase our margins,’ they say, ‘we’re in a competitive market.’  ‘Can we do that?’  I reply, felling that we dribbling out of my mouth.  ‘Won’t someone complain?’  ‘That leaves us in an awkward position.’  And with each burst of we, I’m getting sucked deeper into the grand myth that keeps us all here and convinced that we’re doing something terribly important.  The idea that I am Part of Something Big.

It’s all about the language.  Orwell knew this – in the afterword to 1984 he explains the whole business with newspeak.  Change the way people talk, limit their vocabulary, and you limit the way they think.  I’m trying to hold on to the truth of the matter.  Keeping, if you’ll pardon an extension of the pun, an I on things.  Remembering that I am renting myself to them at a monthly rate, in return for which I will provide a certain amount of brainpower and typing skills as detailed in the contract I signed, with a heavy heart, a few months ago.  That all of this business I’m involved in is making someone else, somewhere on the top floor, considerably richer than it’s making me.

But in this air conditioned room there is no I, there is only we.  And every time I let we out it’s changing how I think. Suddenly I’m personally involved in this thing. Somehow me and the suit on the top floor are in this together. No contracts, no ugly business with money, just a joyful participation in the Great Endeavour of Commerce.  Before you know it I am taking one for the team, staying long after hours and going to bed panicking about things that aren’t my problem at all.

Worryingly it’s beginning to leak into my social life.  ‘How’s the job?’ people ask (usually with horrified curiosity at my defection to the corporate ranks).  ‘Oh,’ I reply, ‘We’re doing something big at the moment. We…’ and I notice that everyone’s looking at me.  Then something awful happens – I try to correct myself and discover that it takes an enormous mental effort, I can feel gears clashing in my head as I try to deprogram my own grammar.  ‘…that is,’ I flounder, ‘I…I mean they…I’ve been employed to help them…’  And so on, but it’s too late.  I am losing the words to express my indenture, just thinking about the real economic relations is becoming unnatural.  I’ve just realised what false consciousness actually feels like as it makes its early assaults on the brain.  

I’ll fight back, I promise. As the we is flung about in air-conditioned rooms I will try to keep in mind that glorious punchline. ‘What do you mean…?’



Watch this space for more dispatches, as our correspondent tries to avoid getting fully digested.


















	 	


March 17, 2006
	INSIDE THE WHALE: Dispatches from within corporate leviathan

Conwy Archives Service
Conwy Community Councils records


Reference code(s): GB 2008 CO/Pa


Held at: Conwy Archives Service


Title: Conwy Community Councils Records

Short Title: Conwy Community Councils records



Creation date(s): 1331-1983 (accumulated 1977-1983)




Level of description: Fonds


Extent: 1.25 cubic metres (26 boxes, 1 large box, 12 vols, 2 rolls)


Name of creator(s): Conwy Community Councils


CONTEXT


Administrative/Biographical history: From the late 19th century, civil parish councils formed the lowest tier of administration in areas covered by Rural District Councils.  In 1974, Local Government re-organisation in Wales led to the renaming of Civil Parishes as Communities, and the creation of Community Councils in urban areas. These bodies inherited miscellaneous records and other papers from their predecessor bodies. Conwy Community Council received papers from Conway Borough Council and Conwy Corporation, and the town charters.  Other bodies represented are Caerhun parish, Capel Curig Parish Council and Community Council, Dolgarrog Parish Council, Dolwyddelan Parish Council, Llanbedr y Cennin Parish Council and Community Council (and earlier records of the Overseers of the Poor for Llanbedr y Cennin Parish), Llansanffraid Glan Conwy Parish, Penmachno Parish Council and Community Council, and Trefriw Parish Council.


CONTENT


 Scope and content/abstract: Records accumulated by Conwy Community Councils, Caernarfonshire, 1331-1983, including poor rate books, Caerhun Parish, 1889-1896; records of Capel Curig Parish Council, 1905-1977; Conwy Borough Charters, 1331-1876; records of Conwy Corporation, 1950-1974; minute books of Dolgarrog Parish Council, 1899-1944; minute books of Dolwyddelan Parish Council, 1894-1929; records of Llanbedr y Cennin parish Overseers of the Poor, Parish and Coummunity Councils, 1798-1983; records of Llansanffraid Glan Conway parish, 1838-1842; and Trefriw parish council minute books, 1895-1962.
  

ACCESS AND USE


Language/scripts of material: English, Welsh, Latin


System of arrangement: Arranged into the following: Caerhun parish; Capel Curig Parish Council; Conwy Borough Charters; records of Conwy Corporation; Dolgarrog Parish Council records; Dolwyddelan Parish Council records; Llanbedr y Cennin Parish Council records; Llansanffraid Glan Conwy Parish records; Penmachno Parish Council records; Trefriw Parish records.


Conditions governing access: No restrictions


Conditions governing reproduction: Usual copyright regulations apply



Finding aids: A hard copy of the schedule is available at Conwy Archives Service.

 
Language codes: engwellat

ARCHIVAL INFORMATION

Appraisal, destruction and scheduling information: All records have been retained

Accruals: Accruals are not expected

                 
Archival history: Deposited at Gwynedd Archive Service. Conwy Borough and Llandudno UDC records formerly included in this collection have been transferred to Conwy Archive Service CB2 and CB7.


Immediate source of acquisition: Transferred from Gwynedd Archive Service, 2000.


ALLIED MATERIALS


Related material: Further papers are Conwy Archive Service, COB10 Nanconwy Rural District Council records; COB2 Conwy Borough records; COB2 (Addnl) Conwy U.D.C. 

DESCRIPTION NOTES

Note: Title supplied from contents of fonds.  Contains material pre-dating the etsablishment of Community Councils in 1974.

Archivist's note: Compiled by Annette Strauch for the ANW project. The following sources were used in the compilation of this description: Conwy Archives Service, Conwy Community Council Records; Conwy County Borough website (www.conwy.gov.uk), viewed 21 October 2003; Taylor, A. J., Conwy Castle and town walls (Cadw: Welsh Historic Monuments 1986); Cyhoeddiadau Mei, Conwy. A History Trail (Penygroes 1986); Gwynedd Archives Service, Place Index: Restricted List of Place Names.

Rules or conventions: This description follows ANW guidelines based on ISAD(G) Second Edition; AACR2 and LCSH

Date(s) of descriptions: October 2003

title: Re: memory loss
text:
Re: memory loss


	| View Thread | Post Response | Return to Index | Read Prev Msg | Read Next Msg |


Different strokes Discussion Board

Re: memory loss

Posted By: ClaireC
Date: Friday, 1 June 2007, at 2:47 p.m.

In Response To: memory loss (claire)


Sorry Claire, I just thought as well that you might be able to get a copy of your hospital records. I am not sure how long they are kept for and 7 years might be too long but it might be worth contacting patient records at the hospital where you were admitted. I got my notes for the births of both of my children, the second of which coincided with my stroke and although some of the terminology was a bit technical,it was very interesting to see a specific timeline over which my pralysis evolved. On admission the little stick man diagram that they drew (it was a maternity hospital after all) showed weak areas, a few hours on,the diagram stated that there was no movement. I have yet to get my epic notes from the stroke unit but I think these might be oo technical and also, like I said, I don't feel I need them now.

You are entitled to see your own notes though there is usually a charge for photocopying etc.

Best of luck if you go down that route

Claire

		Inclusion|  About the curriculum | General teaching requirements | Contact us  |  Help



	
	
		You are here:NC online > PE  >  key stage 3 








	
	
Knowledge, skills and understanding

Teaching should ensure that when 'evaluating and improving performance', connections are made between 'developing, selecting and applying skills, tactics and compositional ideas', and 'fitness and health'.



Acquiring and developing skills


1) Pupils should be taught to:
	refine and adapt existing skills
	develop them into specific techniques that suit different activities and perform these with consistent control.



Selecting and applying skills, tactics and compositional ideas


2) Pupils should be taught to:
	use principles to plan and implement strategies, compositional and organisational ideas in individual, pair, group and team activities
	modify and develop their plans
	apply rules and conventions for different activities.



Evaluating and improving performance


3) Pupils should be taught to:
	be clear about what they want to achieve in their own work, and what they have actually achieved
	
take the initiative to analyse their own and others' work, using this information to improve its quality.




Knowledge and understanding of fitness and health


4) Pupils should be taught:
	how to prepare for and recover from specific activities
	how different types of activity affect specific aspects of their fitness
	the benefits of regular exercise and good hygiene
	how to go about getting involved in activities that are good for their personal and social health and well-being.




Breadth of study




5) During the key stage, pupils should be taught the Knowledge, skills and understanding through four areas of activity. These should include:
	games activities  and three of the following,   at least one of which must be dance or gymnastic activities :


	dance activities
	gymnastic activities
	swimming activities and water safety
	athletic activities
	outdoor and adventurous activities.



Dance activities


6) Pupils should be taught to:
	create and perform dances using a range of complex movement patterns and techniques
	use a range of dance styles and forms
	use compositional principles when composing their dances [for example, motif development, awareness of group relationships, spatial awareness]
	apply performance skills in their dances.



Games activities


7) Pupils should be taught to:
	play competitive invasion, net and striking/fielding games, using techniques that suit the games
	use the principles of attack and defence when planning and implementing complex team strategies
	respond to changing situations in the games.



Gymnastic activities


8) Pupils should be taught to:
	create and perform complex sequences on the floor and using apparatus
	use techniques and movement combinations in different gymnastic styles
	use compositional principles when designing their sequences [for example, changes in level, speed, direction, and relationships with apparatus and partners].



Swimming activities and water safety


9) Pupils should be taught to:
	set and meet personal and group targets in swimming events, waterbased activities, personal survival challenges and competitions
	use a range of recognised strokes, techniques and personal survival skills with technical proficiency.



Athletic activities


10) Pupils should be taught to:
	set and meet personal and group targets in a range of athletic events, challenges and competitions
	use a range of running, jumping and throwing techniques, singly and in combination, with precision, speed, power or stamina.



Outdoor and adventurous activities


11) Pupils should be taught to:
	meet challenges in outdoor activities and journeys
	
use a range of orienteering and problemsolving skills and techniques in these challenges

	identify the roles and responsibilities of individuals within a group when planning strategies
	respond to changing conditions and situations.







		
	
				
	



	

Notes



4 > ICT opportunity

Pupils could use heart and pulse rate monitors and a variety of other measuring and recording devices to collect, analyse and interpret data.

Please select a programme of study requirement to see the relevant note

Thema o'r tudalen hwn:
Busnes gwyrdd







Nid ydym yn gyfrifol am gynnwys gwefannau allanol.
 
			
  
 
   
Swmp gofrestru
Gwneud cais ar ddisg neu drwy e-bost
Os oes angen i chi gofrestru nifer o safleoedd sy'n cynhyrchu gwastraff peryglus ar yr un pryd, gallwch anfon ffeil electronig atom ar ddisg neu drwy e-bost. Y gost ar gyfer hyn yw £18 am bob safle a gofrestrir. Gallwch dalu drwy siec neu drwy BACS. Gallwch gofrestru hyd at 2000 o safleoedd ar yr un pryd.



        
  		Mae angen i chi anfon y ffeil hon atom mewn fformat a elwir yn XML (iaith ychwanegu estynadwy) ar gyfer ein systemau. Nid oes angen i chi ddeall y fformat gan ein bod wedi cynhyrchu taenlen Microsoft Excel a fydd yn creu’r ffeil i chi.
  			
				
				Taenlen swmp gofrestru ar gyfer cynhyrchwyr gwastraff peryglus (MS Excel, 686KB, 3 munud)
				

				Os oes angen i chi gofrestru fwy nag un safle fel cynhyrchydd gwastraff peryglus, defnyddiwch y daenlen hon. Bydd angen i chi arbed y daenlen ar eich gyriant caled yn gyntaf er mwyn ei defnyddio. Mae fersiwn 2.0 y daenlen bellach ar gael - llwythwch y fersiwn newydd i lawr gan ddisodli unrhyw hen fersiynau sydd gennych.
	Defnyddio’r taenlen Excel

		Llwythwch y canllawiau hyn i lawr i gael gwybod sut i gwblhau fersiwn 2.0 o'r daenlen Excel. 
	
				
				Sgema XML (Zip, 6KB, 10 eiliad)
				

				Gallwch greu eich ffeil XML eich hun os ydych yn gwybod sut i wneud hynny. Llwythwch y ddogfen sgema i lawr, sy'n eich caniatáu i wirio bod eich ffeil XML yn gywir.
	
				
				Swmp geisiadau ar ddisg (Acrobat, 319KB, 30 eiliad)
				

				Cwblhewch y ffurflen hon os ydych yn anfon cais swmp gofrestru atom ar ddisg.

Ein cyfeiriad ar gyfer ceisiadau swmp gofrestru ar ddisg

Environment Agency, Quadrant 2, 99 Parkway Avenue, Parkway Business Park, Sheffield. S9 4WG.

Ein cyfeiriad e-bost ar gyfer ceisiadau drwy e-bost

hwnotifications@environment-agency.gov.uk

Ein rhif ffôn ar gyfer ymholiadau am gofrestru

Ffoniwch 08708 502 858 rhwng 9 am a 5pm (unrhyw ddiwrnod o'r wythnos gwaith heblaw am Ddydd Gwener y Groglith, Dydd Nadolig, gwyliau banc neu wyliau cyhoeddus eraill).

The following record was added to the BSHS News and Events Guide database on 30 Mar 2005.  Please note that older announcements, and those relating to past events, may include information and/or links which are no longer valid.
History of Belgian science policy in perspective


Histoire de la politique scientifique en Belgique. Une mise en perspective

22 - 23 avril 2005,

Salle Marie-Thérèse (1er étage), Palais des Académies, Rue Ducale, 1000 Bruxelles




Journées d'étude du Groupe de contact FNRS Histoire comparée des sciences  organisées conjointement avec Studium Generale groupe de contact pour l'histoire des universités




Introduction




In 1927, King Albert I held a memorable speech in favour of the foundation of a national institute for science funding. One year later, the FNRS/NFWO was created, to become the major institution for promoting scientific research in Belgium. It marked a major turning point in the history of science in Belgium and enabled in due time the development of a modern science policy.




However, the usual emphasis put on this single event, has tended to obscure other aspects of the complex interaction between science, government and industry. Obviously, this interaction did not start in 1928, nor was the creation of the FNRS/NFWO a ready made solution to the long standing problem of stimulating scientific innovation. The gradual expansion of political influence in scientific research was sometimes viewed as harmful for the development of pure science and the necessary objectiveness of scientific studies. The emergence of new professional profiles (assistants, researchers) introduced important changes in the organisation of university staff or the management of research activities.




This workshop will attempt to put the creation of the FNRS/NFWO into its proper historical perspective. Belgian science policy will be analysed on a longer historical time scale. Also, attention will be drawn to key figures and developments in twentieth century science in Belgium. To provide the necessary framework for historical analysis, the Belgian situation will be compared to parallel developments in other European countries.




Informations and registration




vantiggelen@memosciences.be

jjheirwe@ulb.ac.be

http://www.memosciences.be






Back to News and Events index

				Friday 28 October 2005 10:18:00

text:
Bookmarks – Socialist Worker



» Back to article

Socialist Worker 1937, 5 February 2005 (www.socialistworker.co.uk)

http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/article.php?article_id=5777

Adverts




Bookmarks


So Now Who Do We Vote For? by John Harris




So Now Who Do We Vote For? (£7.99), the new book from John Harris, confronts the question being asked by millions all over the country who, until now, have been loyal Labour voters. 

Harris looks at the war in Iraq. He goes through what’s happened in hospitals and schools, and catalogues many of the issues which have led people to look for an alternative to Labour. He also lists the Labour MPs who have voted against the war, top-up fees and so on to help people decide which way to vote. 

His analysis of the alternatives—the SNP, Plaid Cymru, the Green Party and the Respect Coalition—will not please everyone. However, the fact that he has written the book is an indication of the problems Blair will face in mobilising the working class voters he will have taken for granted in the past.

John Harris’s previous book, The Last Party (£7.99), about Britpop and Blair is also worth a read.
To order books write to Bookmarks, the socialist bookshop, 1 Bloomsbury Street, London WC1B 3QE, phone 020 7637 1848, e-mail enquiries@bookmarks.uk.com or go to www.bookmarks.uk.com

We are not responsible for the content of other web sites.
 
			
  
 
   
IPPC Directive
The Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control (IPPC) Directive is designed to prevent, reduce and eliminate pollution at source through the efficient use of natural resources. It is intended to help industrial operators move towards greater environmental sustainability.

The directive is implemented by the Pollution Prevention and Control (England and Wales) Regulations 2000. However, these PPC regulations are expected to be superseded by the Environmental Permitting Regulations in 2008.

Under IPPC, a system of permits covers plant operating conditions, emission limits for certain substances to air, land and water and annual reporting of pollutant releases. 

If necessary, permits include measures both for the management of waste generated by the installation and for the protection of soil and groundwater. Where appropriate, permits also have conditions to minimise the impact of a polluting activity beyond our national boundaries.

Emission limits and operating conditions are based on Best Available Techniques (BAT), taking into account the technical characteristics of the installation, its geographic location and local environmental conditions. Measures beyond BAT may also be required, to achieve Environmental Quality Standards.
	IPPC Directive - who does it affect?

		The directive requires industrial and agricultural activities with a high pollution potential to have a permit which can only be issued if certain environmental conditions are met 
	IPPC Directive - what is our role? 

		We are responsible for regulating the majority of all sites that need a PPC permit to operate

 
	Read Defra's practical guide to IPPC

		A good starting point to understand more about Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control (IPPC).

            British Nationalists in Wales WATCH
          
        

      

      
        

      

    

  



  


  
    
  
  

    
  


    
    
      
        Sunday, February 04, 2007

      
      
  
    
    
      
     
        
          Wales v Ireland
        
     
      

    

    


    
      Ok so we didn't win, but wasn't it touching to see Prince William not knowing the words to our national anthem. Will we have to suffer this bloke as well calling himself the Prince of Wales. 

As an aside - I was watching the new series on S4C, Tywysogion, (princes) with English subtitles and I hadn't realised that there was a king of all Wales at the time of Edward Confessor in England, Llywelyn ap Gruffydd, who united the country and even took land from Edward. If he hadn't been killed by a traitor in 1063 it's interesting to think how things would have turned out following William's conquest of England three years later.

However, a few seats away from prince William was Peter Hain, enjoying a game of rugby by two Balkanised teams. Of course, if Hain had his way there wouldn't be a Welsh or Irish team just one big cuddly British team of Brotherhood and Unity. Of course, on the other hand, Hain may just be a hypocrite with no principles.

The one great thing from the game was seeing Aled Brew wear the red jersey. No doubt it's further confirmation that the CRE are right and that independence for Wales would mean racial tension here. Bollocks!

The existence of a national rugby team, like independence, gives Wales the opportunity to build a civic nationality. Aled Brew, a black Welsh speaking  proud Welshman, with a Welsh first name, is living testament of this blindingly obvious truth. It's the CRE and Hain who want to keep Welsh identity an ethnic identity not Welsh nationalists! 

      
 
    

    
    
        
          Posted by Nicholas Michael Morgan

title: The Horses Mouth :: View topic - White line separation
text:
The Horses Mouth :: View topic - White line separation



			The Horses Mouth
the horseshoeing discussion board from the ukhsu
  
					 FAQ   Search   Memberlist   Usergroups 
						 Register 
						
	 Profile   Log in to check your private messages   Log in 

   Back to ukhsu.com      








	White line separation

	  

	    



	   	   The Horses Mouth Forum Index
	  -> horseowners discussion board



	View previous topic :: View next topic  
	Author	Message
	BevGeegee



Joined: 22 Sep 2002
Posts: 3
Location: Nottingham/Derby
		Posted: Thu Jun 01, 2006 1:07 pm    Post subject: White line separation	   
	

	Can someone advise please ??? Bit of a long one I'm afraid......





My 22 year old horse had a mild laminitis bout last Spring due to Cushings disease complications. It showed bruising in all four feet over a period of about three months which eventually grew out one by one. 





Six weeks ago my blacksmith found an abscess in his left forefoot which he partly pared away, applying some hoof putty. Last week when he took the shoe off, about 3 inches of white line separation has appeared on the outside of the foot. He was shod again but when I put him back out in the field, there was muddy water squirting out one of the nailholes about an inch up his foot when he put weight on it. 





Can someone please advise if this is likely to cause futher infection in that foot and if it is normal for white line separation to develop after an abscess ?? Is there anything I can do to help maintain a healthy hoof ??? Will it grow out ??? I have the added complication that he has severe DJD and gets extremely sore if he is in for more than overnight - he's on 2 or 3 bute a day and has been for 4 years (his liver function is the top end of normal !!). 





The other thing I have noticed is that the top 1/2 inch of hoof wall around the coronet band on that foot appears to be indented/constricted all the way around. I've been strip grazing him and haven't noticed any laminitic signs - digital pulse, stance, increased lameness (not really paranoid) so was wondering if this may be just down to restricted grazing ?? If there is sinking of the pedal bone, does the depression described appear all the way around the hoof ??? Does it appear on the fleshy part of the coronet band or on the hoof wall ?? Want to keep him as happy and comfortable as possible and try to counter any further potential problems.


	Back to top		      



	
	john ford



Joined: 25 Oct 2002
Posts: 477
Location: Pucklechurch, Bristol.
		Posted: Sun Jun 04, 2006 9:46 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	Dear Bev, just a very quick answer as I’m off to bed. The laminitis is a result of the Cushions disease, and not the other way around. Also because of the Cushions there is a breakdown of the immune system. Your farrier and veterinary surgeon are fighting a loosing battle with nature in the advanced stages of Cushions disease. We all hope one day there will be a cure for this, but I haven’t heard of anything yet. I'm very sorry to say this, but it is time to call the end of your horse's day's, to end anymore suffering.


	Back to top		      



	
	admin
Site Admin


Joined: 14 May 2002
Posts: 518

		Posted: Sun Jun 04, 2006 10:20 pm    Post subject: 	   
	

	That is the worst case scenario, but there are degrees of severity, and things may not be that bad.





To answer your questions:





The abscess: Can someone please advise if this is likely to cause futher infection in that foot and if it is normal for white line separation to develop after an abscess ?? No and yes.





Is there anything I can do to help maintain a healthy hoof ??? Occasional abscesses are impossible to avoid. Will it grow out ??? Yes.





The other thing I have noticed is that the top 1/2 inch of hoof wall around the coronet band on that foot appears to be indented/constricted all the way around. I've been strip grazing him and haven't noticed any laminitic signs - digital pulse, stance, increased lameness (not really paranoid) so was wondering if this may be just down to restricted grazing ?? 





It may be, but often chronic laminitis can go on without signs of lameness.





If there is sinking of the pedal bone, does the depression described appear all the way around the hoof ??? Yes but usually more at the toe. Does it appear on the fleshy part of the coronet band or on the hoof wall ?? Usually just on the hoof wall. 





Want to keep him as happy and comfortable as possible and try to counter any further potential problems.





It is hard to give specific advice about your horse without knowing more. But I would hope that you can keep him comfortable with support from your vet and your farrier and by getting to know how best to manage your horses laminitis given his particular personality and characteristics and the environment in which he is kept.


	Back to top		      



	
	BevGeegee



Joined: 22 Sep 2002
Posts: 3
Location: Nottingham/Derby
		Posted: Mon Jun 05, 2006 8:16 am    Post subject: Thanks.....	   
	

	For the replies - it gives me a bit more confidence that the white line separation will grow out now. He's not overweight, his coat and eyes are bright and he thought it really funny the other day to push my friends daughter on her bum in a bucket of water - always had a sense of humour !!!!





At the minute, Indy seems content, trots and canters quite happily, albeit a bit lame !!!! He's eating his grub as enthusiastically as ever, loves grooming and being with my other horse and can't wait for visits from people to give him a fuss....





I know that this disease and it's related problems are progressive and he was diagnosed at 17 as having Cushings, so he's living on borrowed time. I'm sure from knowing him inside out for the last 14 years that I'll know when the time comes with him. I'm sure it's not yet for a little while longer.........when that light in his eyes goes out - that'll be the time. 





Thanks again for the replies and if anyone else can offer advice, I'd be more than grateful !!!


	Back to top		      



	
	cowboy_bc



Joined: 07 Dec 2005
Posts: 6
Location: canada
		Posted: Tue Jun 06, 2006 1:02 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	Advice? ask here.





http://www.horseshoes.com/forums/


	Back to top		      



	
	Giles



Joined: 15 May 2002
Posts: 179
Location: Wales
		Posted: Tue Jun 06, 2006 6:24 am    Post subject: Saleman	   
	

	Cowboy,


             She got the good advice, from both a Farrier and a Vet.  Why are you drumming up some busines, think you can do better ?


	Back to top		      



	
	PNB



Joined: 23 Jun 2002
Posts: 646
Location: Wilts, Berks, Ox, Hants, Avon.
		Posted: Tue Jun 06, 2006 11:56 am    Post subject: 	   
	

	Cowboy,





I tend to agree with Giles, as suggested I logged on to you site today, which seems to have emphasis on drawing as much money as possible for doing a bog standard day to day job. I do not approve of fleecing clients who are at their most vulnerable with a sick / distressed animal!! 





We earn enough from shoeing on a daily basis, if the system of service application and routine  advice breaks down leaving a distressed animal it must be our duty to offer support on little more than a costs only basis, it cannot be seen as a massive revenue earner, that is surely is the remit of the Vets!!





PNB.


	Back to top		      



	
	sun tzu



Joined: 29 May 2005
Posts: 22

		Posted: Sat Jun 10, 2006 11:39 pm    Post subject: sdfgsdg	   
	

	sdgsgsdg
