      Scholarly Communications: EU Conference and Commission Statement

    Posted by Michael Jubb, 20 Feb 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		I spent Thursday and Friday last week at an EU conference in Brussels on Scientific Publication in the European Research Area. The conference attracted over 400 representatives of the library, publishing and research communities, and there was an impressive range of speakers from the US as well as across Europe. 

    There was a sense that the debate on open access is beginning to move on at a European level, following the policy statement on open access in December from the European Research Advisory Board (EURAB), and the shorter statement from the European Research Council. 

    Shortly before the conference, the Commission issued its own communication setting out some actions that it intends to take on access to Community-funded research results, the co-funing of research infrastructures, and policy debate and co-ordination. There is much still to debate. Organisations from across Europe, including SPARC Europe and JISC presented a petition with 20,000 signatures urging the Commission to accept the recommendations of the report of the EU-funded Study on the Economic and Technical Evolution of the Scientific Publication Markets of Europe'. Specifically, the petition asks the Commission to establish a European policy mandating published articles arising from EC-funded research to be available after a given time period in open access archives, and to explore with Member States whether and how such policies and open repositories could be implemented. 

    At the same time, 43 publishing organisations have issued the Brussels Declaration laying out ten principles through which scientific, technical and medical (STM) publishing can continue working for the benefit of science and society. 

        All this activity seems to presage further developments in the scholarly communications world over the next few months. The RIN is issuing later this week a statement of the public policy goals for scholarly communications in the UK. It has been endorsed by the key representative bodies for libraries and publishers in the UK, as well as the Wellcome Trust and JISC. We hope it will prove a fruitful contribution to the development of policy in this area.

							Tags: RIN Team Blog 
 
			








  
      How would you answer these easy questions?

    Posted by James Brown, 16 Feb 2007

    

	
		4 comments				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		Next week, we're going to be publishing an important new document. So this week, I've been thinking about how best we can disseminate it. Amongst the usual methods (e.g. the media), I've also been looking at getting the word out on the web. 

There are a large number of issues here, and I think organisations in the HE / research / library / information sector are a long way off from figuring answers. There aren't any established norms, and a lack of consistency in approach. For example - how would you answer these questions...

	There are blogs that I read, which I know carry authority and are popular. Should I email the authors to ask if they will mention our new publication? 
	What can I offer in return? 
	What about smaller or niche blogs? 
	How are relationships developed - 

	Is it about comments? 
	Mutual links? 
	Targeting them with useful content? 
	Emailing them? 



	From an ethical perspective, should you disclose that someone has asked you to mention the report? (cf. publication ethics) 
	How or when can people say no? 
	Or should I just hope that the document is so compelling and interesting that it will arrive on blogs without me having to get in touch? 


A recent email I exchanged with Brian Kelly of UKOLN (who keeps a blog asking lots more questions) helped me sum up what I think is the root of the problem:

How much time should an organisation devote to developing strategic relationships with web-editors and blog-authors? And how open are we all to fostering such relationships?

 
So here's a call to action. Get in touch! My email is james.brown@rin.ac.uk

							Tags: RIN Team Blog 
 
			








  
      E-infrastructure: the UK path to a brave new world

    Posted by Stephane Goldstein, 15 Feb 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		Following a pretty massive collective effort on the part of a large range of agencies (including RIN), last week saw the long-awaited publication of a report on developing the UK's e-infrastructure for science and innovation.  Not the sexiest of titles, but well worth a read, if only because it sets the case for appropriate funding in the Government's forthcoming Comprehensive Spending Review.  The report, somewhat akin to a manifesto structured around six broad themes, underlines the dangers of neglecting infrastructure when seeking to build - in the Government's own terms - a successful knowledge-based economy.

   

  No-one, outside select circles at HM Treasury, knows how much influence the proposals and ideas will have in practice, but there can be no harm in spreading the word about them - particularly if your constituency MP happens to be Gordon Brown, Stephen Timms, Dawn Primarolo, John Healy or Ed Balls.

   

							Tags: RIN Team Blog | e-research | funding | government 
 
			








  
      open access, quality and quantity

    Posted by Stephane Goldstein, 09 Feb 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		Leading open access publisher BioMed Central held a workshop (“Open access: how can we achieve quality and quantity?”) at the Royal College of Physicians, in London, on 8 February.  Apart from an unfortunate piece of irony - holding a meeting on open access in a room full of locked bookcases - the event was interesting, well-organised and confident, even if somewhat self-congratulatory.  Two points in particular caught my attention.

   

  1. Publishing meets social networking?  OK, it's yet another cliché, but there was quite a buzz about the potential to develop post-publication interactivity on journal content.  In a sense, this stretches the scope and meaning of 'publication' by allowing for open commentary and annotation, and hence dialogue and debate, on a dynamic and ongoing basis.  The notable example presented at the meeting was the case of PLoS One, but there may be others.  This is not a substitute for peer review, but could provide for a form of quality assessment by facilitating critical discussion by the community.  Hype or hope?

   

  2. How do researchers (and, in the case of clinicians, practitioners) use journals?  The meeting pointed to cases of poor or even dangerous conclusions being reached through reading abstracts rather than whole journal articles.  Contenting oneself with reading just the abstract is hardly unusual, and there are all sorts of good reasons for this - one of which may be that only the abstract is freely available (which, of course, open access proponents don't fail to underline). The problem is when this leads to misinterpretation, especially if the abstract is poorly-written. So is there a case for seeking empirical evidence on how journals are used - and perhaps by extension on how content is cited?  What research has there been in this area?  Comments welcome...

							Tags: RIN Team Blog | journals | publishing 
 
			








  
      British Library

    Posted by Michael Jubb, 09 Feb 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		­

  As many of you will have read, there are fears that the British Library will face cuts in the coming Spending Review, and it has produced a briefing note setting out what the implications would be. It has set up a forum for supporters to keep everyone informed and engaged with developments. It is also asking supporters to write to supporters_forum@bl.uk  to say why the British Library is important to them, and to give permission to use what they say to help make the case to Government.

   

  There is also a petition on the new e-petitions service on the

        10 Downing Street website. It would be good if it were to receive a large number of signatures.

							Tags: RIN Team Blog | funding | government | library 
 
			








  
      Starry-eyed techno-optimsim? Apple says otherwise..

    Posted by James Brown, 07 Feb 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		­

There's a smart video on YouTube called web 2.0.. the machine is us/ing us. It's made by a cultural anthropologist who explains the story of web 2.0, and how it's changing the world. 

It's been called "about as starry-eyed as techno-optimism gets," and in truth it does neglect to mention that digital assets can be newly controlled as well as newly distributed.

On the other hand... 

Apple's CEO Steve Jobs written an open letter to the music industry coming out against DRM. I should say that again - Apple is now against DRM.

Digital Rights Management (an umbrella term for technologies that copyright owners have used to control access and usage of digital data - wikipedia) is a very controversial topic, with critics saying that is used to restrict fair-use, anti-competitive, and not in the spirit of an open web future.

Apple's iTunes Music Store has used DRM for years - to the extent that you can't play music bought there on any device other than an iPod. If Apple really are ready now to change to non-DRM, this could be a huge step-forward. 

Cynics have called it link-bait and propaganda, but if the music industry sits up, it could mean that that YouTube video above isn't quite as starry-eyed as we thought. Or perhaps i'm just a techno-optimist...

							Tags: RIN Team Blog 
 
			








  
      Cataloguing? Throw it out the window

    Posted by James Brown, 05 Feb 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		The website you're currently browsing (many thanks) has adopted a tagging system, for an alternative method of navigation and to help you, esteemed reader, to find similar and relevant content. 

Tagging is an extremely popular concept now - indeed, Flickr announced a few days ago that their tagging system was so popular that they were having to cap the maximum number of tags to 75, prompting an immediate backlash from many users. 

But do you really need more than 75 keywords to describe a photo? Do you need that many to describe any kind of asset? 

This is where tagging differs dramatically from the much older art of cataloguing. With catalogues, the vocabulary is controlled, and carefully applied. There's a supply of finite keyword pick-lists: the Library of Congress Subject Headings, the Medical Subject Headings (MESH) or even the Dewey Decimal System. 

The assumed knowledge was that without a way to account for the ambiguities of language and meaning, there is chaos.

But as Web experts adaptivepath put it: tagging throws that whole concept right out the window. An interesting thought - what would happen to a library if any librarian, frequent user, fleeting user, or one-off amateur was in control of the cataloguing?

I imagine that you wouldn't be able to find a specific book, but you'd stumble across much more than you bargained for.

							Tags: RIN Team Blog | catalogue | internet 
 
			








  
      Visualising the Royal Society Archive of Papers

    Posted by James Brown, 02 Feb 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		When the Royal Society recently provided an access to the archive of papers in their prestigious scientific journal, I bet they didn't foresee this...

A man named Chris Harrison (who I can't seem to find any information on, aside from the fact that he is interested in ceramics, travel, motorbikes and computer science) has completed an extremely large timeline, depicting the archive of papers published in the journal from 1665 to 2005.

The visualisation displays papers chronologically, paper titles sorted alphabetically within a year. The size of the author's name reflects how prolific they were. Some interesting patterns emerge: 

	
Paper titles become shorter over time. 
	There is a notable decrease in the quantity of papers published per volume starting around 1761, which significantly rebounds in 1970. 
	There are numerous prolific authors in the 1700s, which are unmatched in any other time period. 


 



							Tags: RIN Team Blog 
 
			








  
      33 reasons why librarians are irreplacable

    Posted by James Brown, 01 Feb 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		­

From Phil Bradley's blog - there's an American website aimed at prospective college students talking about the "existential crisis" that librarians are facing at a time when they are perhaps needed the most. 

From the 33 listed reasons:

1. Not everything is available on the internet

8.  Digitisation is going to take a while. A long while

12.  Library attendance isn't falling, it's just more virtual now

32.  Libraries are a stopgap to anti-intellectualism.

I agree with Phil - the rest of the list is well worth a read.

							Tags: RIN Team Blog 
 
			








  
      Copyright, Publishing and the Zwolle Group

    Posted by Michael Jubb, 25 Jan 2007

    

	
		0 comment				
			Add your views
		
		  		
 
	

	
		An article in the latest D-Lib magazine provides a history of the activities of the Zwolle Group, which was established in 2001 as a partnership between librarians and publishers. Representatives come mainly from the Netherlands, the UK and the US, there is representation also from Australia, the Czech Republic, Israel and Spain. JISC and SURF (its Netherlands counterpart) have been prominent among the organisations supporting the Group, and SURF hosts its website. Publisher involvement has been through the Association of Learned and Professional Society Publishers (ALPSP), the Emerald Group, and the American Physical Society.

   

  The Group has an ambitious mission, to develop and promote balanced approaches to rights management, with the aim of establishing maximum access to scholarly information. And early on it adopted a central objective and a series of principles to inform its work:

   

  Objective:

   

  To assist stakeholders – including authors, publishers, librarians, universities and the public – to achieve maximum access to scholarship without compromising quality or academic freedom and without denying aspects of costs and rewards involved.

   

  The Zwolle Principles: 

	Achievement of this objective requires the optimal management of copyright in scholarly works to secure clear allocation of rights that balance the interests of all stakeholders.

           
	Optimal management may be achieved through thoughtful development and implementation of policies, contracts, and other tools, as well as processes and educational programs, (collectively "Copyright Management") that articulate the allocation of rights and responsibilities with respect to scholarly works.

           
	Appropriate Copyright Management and the interests of various stakeholders will vary according to numerous factors, including the nature of the work; for example, computer programs, journal articles, databases and multimedia instructional works may require different treatment.

           
	In the development of Copyright Management, the primary focus should be on the allocation to various stakeholders of specific rights.

           
	Copyright Management should strive to respect the interests of all stakeholders involved in the use and management of scholarly works; those interests may at times diverge, but will in many cases coincide.

           
	All stakeholders in the management of the copyright in scholarly works have an interest in attaining the highest standards of quality, maximising current and future access, and ensuring preservation; stakeholders should work together on an international basis to best achieve these common goals and to develop a mutually supportive community of interest.

           
	All stakeholders should actively promote an understanding of the important implications of copyright management of scholarly work and encourage engagement with the development and implementation of Copyright Management tools to achieve the overarching objective. 


  Much of the work of the group has centred around copyright, and producing guidelines and a toolbox for authors and publishers seeking to develop new kinds of agreements for the publication of scholarly works; and there has been a major comparative analysis of copyright law as it affects scholarly publication in twelve different countries.

   

  Five years down the line, some valuable resources have been created. But it is not clear exactly where the project will go from here. Copyright remains a key issue in the continuing discussions and debates around the future of the scholarly communications process, and the changing roles of the key groups of players in that process. It seems unlikely that the last word has been said on these issues. But what further work needs to be done?

						'Falling water, River Mellte, Wales', 						Annette Price, 2006

					

										'Falling water, River Mellte, Wales'

						Annette Price


						
						17 December 2006


						Water falls down the face of dark rock, tumbling and swirling.  The low light level of approaching dusk frees it to run softly through the frame, hiding or revealing that which lies within it.  The fluidity of water, creating ever changing swirling patterns, fascinates me as it transforms from still to surging,  trickling, tumbling from the sky as rain or moving softly over rock.  Part of a series titled Moving Water.

title: Printed Materials Collection - A list of manuscripts, letters, theses & relating to the Welsh Colony in Patagonia
text:
Printed Materials Collection - A list of manuscripts, letters, theses & relating to the Welsh Colony in Patagonia












A list of manuscripts, letters, theses & relating to the Welsh Colony in Patagonia 


Compiled by Eirionedd A. Baskerville




Key:	
W	Welsh

		S	Spanish

		E	English



MANUSCRIPTS

	Portions of the manuscripts of three published works by D. S. Davies relating to the Welsh Colony in Patagonia.  NLW MS 2385B  W.



	'Horoscope Y Wladfa Gymreig' (poem).  NLW MS 2389D  W.



	'Penillion ar ymadawiad John Lewis Mus.Bac. a'i deulu i Patagonia'.  ('Verses on the departure of John Lewis...and his family to Patagonia').  NLW MS 3198C.  W.



	D. S. Davies's diary with entry for 19 June 1886, 'Hwyliad y fintai fawr 470 i'r Wladfa'.  NLW MS 4611A.  W.



	Letters, press cuttings, and other papers, most of them relating to 'The Welsh Colonial and General Trading Co. Limited' (Cwmni Ymfudol a Masnachol y Wladfa Gymreig...) and to Congregational afffairs in Wales, &c.  They include a list of subscribers in the USA (mainly Welshmen) for shares in the Colonising Company, and letters, 1871-1911, from [R. D. Edwards] ('Derfel'), E. Herber Evans ('Herber'), H. Tobit Evans, Thomas Gee, William Griffith (Holyhead), Walter D. Jeremy, D. Ll. Jones (Ruthin, secretary of the Colonising Company), George James Jones (Findlay, Ohio, USA), J. Spinther James ('Spinther'), Lewis Jones, Michael D. Jones, R. Gwesyn Jones (Utica, USA), William S. Jones ( the Office of Baner America, Scranton, USA), Job Miles (Aberystwyth), Thomas Nicholas, Joseph Parry (Mus. Doc.), Thomas Rees (Swansea), Daniel Rowlands (Normal College, Bangor), Edward Stephen ('Tanymarian'), John Thomas (Liverpool), Robert Thomas ('ap Vychan'), &c.  NLW MS 4616B.  W, E.



	A register of shareholders of the American Branch Office of the Welsh Colonising and General Trading Co., (Compañia Mercantil Chubut).  NLW MS 4617E.  E.



	A Guia de Campaña, or permit, signed by Hugh Griffith, 1896, and issued to Llwyd ap Iwan;  and press cuttings of events in the colony.  NLW MS 5934D.  S.



	Legal documents and business letters addressed to Mihangel ap Iwan, 1905-35, relating mainly to the Compañia Mercantil Chubut and its affairs;  notes by Mihangel ap Iwan, including 'Nodiadau ar ymddygiad yr CMC (Cwmni Masnachol Camwy...)';  letters (or copies of letters) between Mihangel ap Iwan and officials of the company, with printed annual reports and other statements of the company for various years.  NLW MS 5935E.  W, S. E.



	Miscellaneous papers described by Mihangel ap Iwan as 'Gohebiaeth neu lythyrau yn rhoi cipdrem ar fywyd beunyddiol Estancia Nant y Pysgod ym Mhatagonia' (correspondence or letters which give a glimpse of life at the Nant y Pysgod Estancia in Patagonia), and comprising correspondence between Mihangel ap Iwan and his nephews, Mihangel Gruffydd ap Iwan and Llewelyn Huw ap Iwan, superintendent of Nant y Pysgod, and letters to Mihangel ap Iwan from E. F. Hunt ('mab ffarm o ym[y]l Rhuthin, Dyffryn Clwyd'), R. Powell Jones, and Philip J. Rees;  copies of articles by Mihangel ap Iwan in Y Drafod, and in various Buenos Aires newspapers, with illustrations of Port Madryn, Rawson, and other places in 'Y Wladfa Gymreig';  and miscellanea.  NLW MS 5936D.  W, S, E.



	Various accounts, &c., 1861-81, giving details of receipts and disbursements of the Secretary, Treasurer, &c., of Y Wladychfa Gymreig, Patagonia.  Among them are balance sheets, 'Rhestr o'r arian a dalwyd gan wŷr Lleyrpwll (Liverpool) tuag at dreuliau y Wladychfa Gymreig', 'Cyfrifon New Bay', 'Cyfrif Chupat', 'Arwerthiant Eiddo Elis Griffith yr hwn a voddodd yn y Gamwy Mawrth 17, 1876.  Gwerthwyd ar ran y perthynasau dros [?] Lywydd y Wladva gan R. J. Berwyn Arwerthwr...', 'Papurau amodol y Fos Vawr', &c.  NLW MS 7254D.  W.



	'A list of papers of the Welsh Colony, 1865-78.  With Mr W. C. Rhys'.  NLW MS 7255E.  W.



	'Names of members of the Colony's Medical Society, for the use of Dr Mihangel ap Iwan, 1889'.  NLW MS 7255E.  W.



	'Ymchwildaith i'r Andes', being Llwyd ap Iwan's journal of a journey to the Andes, 1888, together with measurements relating to 'Camlas Gaiman' and other water channels in Patagonia.  NLW MS 7257A.  W.



	Two exercise-books containing a journal, written in 1888 by Llwyd ap Iwan, of life in the Welsh Colony in Patagonia;  the journal was sent by the writer to his father, the Rev. Michael D. Jones, for publication in Welsh newspapers.  NLW MS 7258-9C.  W.



	'The Chubut valley.  The origin, history, development and prospects of the Welsh Colony, with an account of several expeditions and travels in Patagonia', written by Llwyd ap Iwan c. 1898-9.  NLW MS 7260-2C.  E.



	Cuttings from Buenos Aires and other newspapers, mainly of contributions by Mihangel ap Iwan, such as 'Down South or Adventures in the Patagonian Cordilleras', &c.  NLW MS 7263D.  E, W.



	A newspaper-cuttings book used by John S. Williams of Gaiman, Chubut, Patagonia, and afterwards of Aberystwyth.  It contains press cuttings from Y Drafod, Y Gwerinwr (El Democrata), and other newspapers, including contributions by John S. Williams himself, official communications, written or received by him, and a copy of the list of subjects for 'Eisteddfod y Gaiman...8fed Hydref, 1908', &c.  NLW MS 7264E.  W, S, E.



	'I'w Urddas Brenhinol Tywysog Cymru fel arwydd fechan o barch ac edmygedd Cymry godre'r Andes, Archentina', being an address, with autograph signatures, presented to HRH the Prince of Wales in March 1931 on his visit to the Argentine by 'The Pioneers of Cwm Hyfryd' ('Colonia 16 de Octubre') in the Welsh Colony in Patagonia.  Among the signatories are John D. Evans, 'Arloesydd', and Mihangel ap Iwan.  NLW MS 7265B.  W, E.



	Holograph manuscript of an article on 'Ysgol yn yr Andes' by Lewis Humphreys.  NLW MS 8407C.  W.



	Material used by Jonathan Ceredig Davies in his Patagonia:  a description of the country (Treorchy, 1892).  NLW MS 8545-8B.  E.



	Poster for J. Ceredig Davies's lecture, 'Un mlynedd ar bymtheg yng Ngwlad y Cewri', at Llanafan, 31 Jan. 1893.  NLW MS 8554B.  W.



	A poem:  Patagonia' ('Cwmorthin Competitive Meeting, 11 and 12 May, 1876').  NLW MS 8603E.  W.



	Notes, reports, and cash settlements of W. J. Parry on his visits to Buenos Aires and Chubut on behalf of the Directors of the Welsh Patagonian Gold Field Syndicate, Ltd.  NLW MS 8783-4.  E.



	Particulars by Mihangel ap Iwan concerning the consumption of meat by rural workers in Nant-y-Pysgod, 1928-9.  NLW MS 9651A.  W, S.



	Diary entries by Llwyd ap Iwan, brother of Mihangel ap Iwan, in Y Dyddiadur Annibynol, 1887, and Renshaw's Almanack and Diary, 1886.  NLW MS 9652-3A.  W, E.



	Press cuttings, including the issue of Y Drafod, 12 June 1925, containing obituary notices and appreciation of the life of Mrs Anne Lloyd Jones, widow of Michael D. Jones;  press cuttings relating to the Chubut settlement.  NLW MS 9656E.  W, S.



	A patent to Mihangel ap Iwan to practise as a doctor in the Argentine, 1927;  autographs of guests at a banquet given to Mihangel ap Iwan, 1923;  programme of the consecration of the St David's Lodge of Freemasons, No. 3952, at Buenos Aires, 1920.  NLW MS 9656E.  S, E.



	A memorial card for Ebenezer M. Morgan, Trelew, 1910.  NLW MS 9656E.  E.



	A typescript copy of a report on the Welsh Colony in the Chubut valley, Patagonia, prepared by the Rev. David Powell Richards, MA, Chaplain in the Royal Navy, and addressed by him from HMS Flora, in Monte Video, 8 April 1901, to the Hon. Sir William A. C. Barrington, KCMG, HM Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary at Buenos Aires.  Accompanying the report are numerous appendices and insets, including a typescript statement of authorities as to the boundaries of Argentina;  typescript extracts from The Review of the River Plate, 8 Sept. 1900, and Y Drafod, 9 Nov. 1900, touching the results of recent muncipal elections in Chubut;  a typescript copy of a letter, 4 July 1900, from R. Groome, Commodore, HMS Flora, to the Secretary of the Admiralty, reporting on his visit to the Welsh Colony;  manuscript copies of a letter, 29 Aug. 1901, from Hy. Vansittart Neale, Admiralty, to A. K. Wilson, Vice-Admiral Commanding, Channel Squadron, and a letter, 11 Sept. 1901, from H. D. Barry, Captain, HMS Mars, at Lagos, to Vice-Admiral A. K. Wilson, touching arrangements for an interview between the Rev. D. P. Richards and the High Commissioner for Canada;  draft minutes of a general meeting of Welsh settlers at Gaiman Chapel, 22 Aug. 1898, and of the 1st and 2nd meetings of the National Council Committee appointed by the general meeting, 30 Aug.-7 Oct. 1898;  a manuscript copy of a letter from the Welsh settlers to the British Minister in Buenos Aires, 18 June 1900, protesting against their arrests by the Argentine authorities, and a manuscript copy of a letter, 5 March 1902, from [D. P. Richards] from HMS Mars, Channel Squadron, at Tetuan, touching the proposal for the restoration of the Colony to British territory;  and press cuttings.  NLW MS 10746E.  E.



	An album of press cuttings relating to the transfer of settlers from the Chubut Valley, Argentina, to Canada, 1902.  NLW MS 10816E.  E.



	Photographs of specimen pages, 1885-91, from the first minute book of the Gaiman Council in Patagonia.  NLW MS 10844A.  W, S.



	A note of agreement, 6 Jan. 1885, between 'Luis' [Lewis] Jones, Edward J. Williams, and Thomas Davies, members of the Luis Jones y Cia, promoting a railway from Port Madryn to the Chubut Colony.  The agreement is signed by Luis Jones and E. J. Williams, and is written in the latter's hand.  NLW MS 12194E.  E.



	Journals of Lewis Jones, 1862-3, largely recording his exploratory visit to Patagonia.  NLW MS 12198-9A.  W.



	A volume of manuscript notes and press cuttings relating to the imprisonment in 1882-3 of Lewis Jones and R. J. Berwyn on a charge of organising an agitation to secure the rights of the Welsh settlers.  The title-page is worded 'Carchariad a'i ganlyniadau Rhag 20/82-Mawrth 21/83.  L. J.'  NLW MS 12200A.  S, E, W.



	A holograph essay (35pp.) by Lewis Jones entitled 'Llenyddiaeth yn y Wladfa' ('Literature in the Welsh Colony').  NLW MS 12201A.  W.



	Holograph poetry and short plays by Lewis Jones.  The titles include 'Y Teiriaith (Gwyl y Glaniad, 1883)', 'Vy ngalarnad am Berry Rhys...[18]83', 'Gwyl y Glaniad 1884...', 'Anerchiad Eisteddvod 1883', 'Cwrcwd.  Cerdd ddesgrifiadol o fywyd yn y Wladfa...1872', 'Anerchiad erbyn Eisteddvod y Vron Deg...1880', 'Anerchiad i dervynu tymhor 1882, Cylch Caerantur...', 'Galarnad am Aaron Jenkins...1879', 'Dal y Drvch Erbyn Gwyl y Glaniad 1874', &c.  NLW MS 12202A-3C.  W.



	Of the Patagonians by Thomas Pennant of Downing.  NLW MS 12706E.  E.



	Holograph copies of two songs entitled 'Y Llyn' and 'Y Môr', words and music by [Hugh Davies, 1853-1938], 'Alltud yr Andes';  press cuttings containing poems by Hugh Davies;  and a letter from R. E. Jones (Hugh Davies's nephew), Cynwyd, Corwen, to [?The Librarian, National Library of Wales], 1938 (information regarding his uncle).  NLW MS 12902C.  W.



	Letters or documents of Hugh Davies ('Hugo'r Andes').  NLW MS 14350A.  W.



	A selection of poems of the Welsh Colony, written by various authors.  Competition no. 18, Colony's Chaired Eisteddfod, 1950.  By 'Cyfaill y Beirdd'.  NLW MS 15402C.  W.



	Correspondence and miscellanea relating to the Welsh Colony in Patagonia.  NLW MS 16254B.  W, S.



	List of Welsh books, and books pertaining to Wales, provided by David Roberts, publisher, of Patagonia and London, for Charles Ashton;  letters and postcards.  NLW MS 16275C.  E, W.



	Letters to Owen Williams, poetry by him, miscellanea re Patagonia.  NLW MS 16508D.  W, S, E.



	An account of a voyage from London to Chubut by the Rev. William Phillips, and records of the Welsh Patagonian Goldfields Syndicate Ltd, 1891-2.  NLW MS 16509B.  W.



	Lecture, 'Fifteen Years in Patagonia', 1902, by W. Casnodyn Rhys.  NLW MS 16653B.  WCR 1.  E.



	'Pioneers of Patagonia', chapters I-XIII, by W. Casnodyn Rhys.  NLW MS 16654C.  WCR 2.  E.



	Poems by W. Casnodyn Rhys, 1868-1930.  NLW MS 16655D.  WCR 4.  W, S, E.



	An invitation to W. Casnodyn Rhys to attend a public meeting of the Chubut Mercantile Co., 1927.  It went into liquidation soon after this date.  List of shareholders of the Chubut Mercantile Co.;  press cuttings of articles on the Baptist cause in Argentina.  NLW MS 16656D.  W, E, S.



	Carriage licence issued to W. Casnodyn Rhys by the local Council of Rawson, 1891.  NLW MS 16656D.  S.



	'Covrestr Teuluaidd' (family register) kept by W. Casnodyn Rhys;  memorial card for Rhys Thomas, Frongoch, Chubut, who died 4 Sept. 1924, aged 68.  NLW MS 16656D.  W.



	'Hela morloi ar yr Arvordir Patagonaidd', by E. F. Hunt, c. 1893.  NLW MS 16657D.  W.



	William Owen Roberts's address on 'Llyfryddiaeth Dyffryn Camwy', &c.  NLW MS 16827B.  W.



	Records of the Welsh Patagonian Gold Fields Syndicate Ltd, 1891-2, and an advertisement for the company which mined for gold in the Andes.  NLW MS 16956D.  E, S.



	Incomplete essay, 'Masnach y Wladfa' ('Trade in the Welsh Colony'), probably by R. J. Berwyn, 1879 Eisteddfod.  1880.  (See R. Bryn Williams, Rhyddiaith y Wladfa, p. 15).  NLW MS 17526A.  W.



	Typescript copy of a report received by the Foreign Office on the Welsh Colony in Patagonia, n. d.  NLW MS 17743E.  W, E.



	List of the manuscripts of T. Benbow Phillips, and portions of the manuscripts copied at Esquel, Jan. 1960.  NLW MS 18175B.  RBW MS 1.  W, E.



	Diary of Joseph Seth Jones giving an account of the voyage of the Mimosa to Patagonia in 1865, and for 14-21 March 1866.  NLW 18176B.  RBW MS 2.  W.



	Typescript copy of the minute-book of the Welsh courts in Patagonia, 1872-81.  NLW MS 18178C.  RBW MS 4.  W.



	Pamphlet relating to the Welsh Colony by Lewis Jones, 1869.  Printed.  NLW MS 18179B.  RBW MS 5.  W.



	Extracts from the registers of Vrondeg Baptist Chapel, 1877-80.  (Typescript).  NLW MS 18182B.  RBW MS 8.  W.



	An account of irrigation, &c., in the Welsh Colony by Dafydd Iâl Jones, 1960.  NLW MS 18183C.  RBW MS 9.  W.



	Extracts from the minute books of the Gaiman Council, 1885-91.  NLW MS 18184C.  RBW MS 10.  W.



	Galeses en el Chubut.  (Romance) por Andres Fidalgo.  En Trelew, 1950.  A poem to the Welsh Colony's pioneers by Jorge Manrique, one of Argentina's young poets, which won the prize at Comodoro Rivadavia in 1949.  NLW MS 18185C.  RBW MS 11.  S.



	Primeras paginas de historia del Chubut.  Early history of the Colony composed by the Department of Culture of the Province of Chubut, 1958.  NLW MS 18186E.  RBW MS 12.  S.



	Concierto Coral.  Programme of a concert held in the Old Chapel, Gaiman, 23 Jan. 1960, with a copy of the music which includes the tune Hafren, composed by Dalar Evans, Cwm Hyfryd.  1960.  Printed and cyclostyled.  (Latin, S, W, E).  NLW MS 18187E.  RBW MS 13.



	Welsh bank note for ten shillings and a photocopy of another for one pound, 1865.  NLW 18188-9A.  RBW MSS 14-15.  W.



	Deed relating to the land of Vrondeg Chapel in the Colony.  1880.  NLW MS 18191A.  RBW MS 17.  W.



	Copies of manuscripts kept in Gaiman:  (a) Constitution of the Camwy Education Society;  (b) letter relating to the calling of a minister to Vrondeg Chapel, 1878;  (c) letter relating to an inquiry concerning a member of Vrondeg Chapel, 1877.  NLW MS 18192C.  RBW MA 18.  W.



	Plans of Llanddewi church, Chubut.  1891.  NLW MS 18193F.  RBW MA 19.



	Agreements between Llwyd ap Iwan and the Phoenix Patagonian Mining Co.  1897.  Copy.  NLW MS 18194A.  RBW MS 20.  W.



	Manuscript of poetry by David Owen, composed whilst pioneering Choele-Choel.  1902.  NLW MS 18195C.  RBW MS 21.  W.



	Agreement between (1) David Jones and Joseph Jones and (2) Michael Doolan relating to the cutting of peat in the Colony.  1866.  NLW MS 18199B.  RBW MS 25.  E.



	Minute book of the Calvinistic Methodist Monthly Meetings in the Colony, 1881-1925.  NLW Ms 18202D.  RBW MS 28.  W.



	Rules of the St David Society, Trelew, Chubut.  1958.  NLW MS 18203E.  RBW MS 29.  S.



	Semana de Trelew del 20 al 27 de Noviembre de 1954.  Programa oficial de Actos.  Official programme of 'Trelew Week' to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the death of Lewis Jones.  1954.  Printed.  NLW MS 18204B.  RBW MS 30.  S.



	CAMWY.  The first issue of a periodical.  1961.  Typescript.  NLW MS 18205C.  RBW MS 31.  W, S, E.



	Report of a public meeting in Blaenau Ffestiniog and an advertisement relating to the proposed Welsh Colony.  Reprinted from the Herald Gymraeg.  1865.  NLW MS 18209F.  RBW MS 35.  W.

	Letters, 1871 & 1905, from Griffith Griffiths ('Gutyn Ebrill'), Ffestiniog and Gaiman, Chubut, (the first, and perhaps both, to J. Jones, Dinas Mawddwy).  Bob Owen Collection, 32/29-30.  W.



	Letter from John Camwy Evans.  Bob Owen Collection, 35/6/23.  W.



	Letters from poets, literary figures, &c., including Eluned Morgan.  Sir O. M. Edwards Papers, 10.  W.



	Letters, 1910-38, from Eluned Morgan.  Moelona Papers, 4-7.  W.



	Twenty-six letters and cards, 1916-23, 1931, from Eluned Morgan to W. Anthony Davies, press cuttings, &c.  Mrs E. Anthony Davies Papers.  W, S.



	Letters to the Rev. John Dyfnallt Owen ('Dyfnallt') from Rev Tudur Evans, Dedwyddfa, Gaiman, Chubut, Jan.-Dec. 1950 (6). J. Dyfnallt Owen Collection, 182-7.  W.



	Letters to the Rev. John Dyfnallt Owen ('Dyfnallt') from Dewi Jones, Delvan, Gaiman, Chubut, Jan. 29, May 1905 (2), one undated.  J. Dyfnallt Owen Collection, 288.  W.



	Letter to the Rev. John Dyfnallt Owen ('Dyfnallt') from H. T. Samuel, Chubut, 1948, Aug. 12 (1). J. Dyfnallt Owen Collection, 533.  W.



	Letters to T. E. Ellis from Thomas Ellis, Cynlas.  Personal, general comments and local news.  Patagonian settlement, ?1880s-1890s.  T. E. Ellis Papers, 532-5.  W.



	Letter to T. E. Ellis from Lewis Jones, 21 Dec. 1892.  Invitation to visit Patagonia to recover from his illness.  T. E. Ellis Papers, 1149.  W.



	Letters, 25 Oct. 1890, and 28 June 1893, to T. E. Ellis from Lewis Jones.  T. E. Ellis Papers, 1150.  W.



	Correspondence, 1964-6, relating to Patagonia (1965), including a letter from R. Bryn Williams.  Cymdeithas Llyfrau Ceredigion Papers, 35.  W.



	Eluned Morgan's letters to Myfyr Hefin (the Rev. David Bowen).  David Bowen and Ben Bowen Papers, DPG 1/2  W.



	Correspondence, 1913, relating to the Churches in Patagonia belonging to the Calvinistic Methodist Church of Wales, which possess no deeds.  CMA 18367.  W, E.



	Eluned Morgan's letters to the Rev. W. Nantlais Williams.  CMA 28481-28507.  W.



	Photocopies of twenty-five letters, 1924-37, from the Rev. W. Nantlais Williams, Ammanford, to Eluned Morgan, Patagonia.  NLW Facs 211.  W.



	Letter from Robert Roberts, Cwm Hyfryd, Patagonia, relating to the murder of Llwyd ap Iwan, 1910.  NLW Facs 369/12.  W.



	A photocopy of the last letter, 1925, written by 'Glan Caeron' (William H Hughes, 1866-1926). Chubut, Patagonia, to his relatives in Wales.  NLW Facs 369/49.  W.



	Photocopies of four letters in Welsh, 1915. from members of the Owen family who emigrated to Moora, Western Australia, from Patagonia, to their relative Maggie Owen in Abergele.  NLW Facs 369/51.  W.



	Photocopy of a letter, ?1999, from Ted Roberts, Perth, Australia, to John Owens, Abergele, concerning Welsh immigrants at Moora, north of Perth, Western Australia, many of whom came from Patagonia.  NLW Facs 369/56.



	Photocopies of a letter from W. H. Hughes ('Glan Caeron'), Dolavon, 1925, to Mrs Ellen Jones ('Nel Fach y Bwcs'), Emporium, Llandysul, sympathising with her on the death of her father, his 'old friend' [John Davies] a former inhabitant of the Welsh Colony in Patagonia, and containing news of developments in the country and population growth.  NLW Facs 369/59. W.



	A letter, November 1997, from Hazel Charles Evans, Chubut, Patagonia, to William. Howells, Aberystwyth, regarding Welsh books sent to Patagonia.  NLW ex 1884/1. 
	.



	Transcript of a letter, 12 Dec. 1918, from Eluned Morgan, Rio de Janeiro, to her Sunday School class at Minny Street chapel, Cardiff.  Minor Lists and Summaries 1982.  (D Myrddin Lloyd Papers, 27).  W.



	Letter, 12 Dec. 1918, written in shorthand, from Eluned Morgan to her Sunday School class at Minny Street chapel, Cardiff, and a typescript copy.  Mrs E. Anthony Davies Papers.  W.



	Letter relating to the Patagonian Junior Branch of the League of Nations.  League of Nations Papers file 256(3).  E.



	Letter, 27 Sept. 1905, from Eluned Morgan to Daniel Rees.  Mentions T. Gwynn Jones and her desire for him to go to the Colony for the sake of his health.  T. Gwynn Jones Collection, B120.  W.



	Letter of resignation of the Rev. R. J. Jones, minister of Tŵr-gwyn Chapel, Bangor, on his departure to minister in the Welsh Colony in Patagonia, 1919.  Minor Deposit 1450A (ii).  W.



	Letter, 1942, from Evan Thomas, Gaiman.  Kate Roberts Papers, 7306.  W.



	R. Bryn Williams's letters relating to Cymry Patagonia and Eluned Morgan's books.  Kate Roberts Papers, 7806-17.  W.



	Letter, 8 Nov. 1941, from Wmffra Jones, Patagonia.  W. J. Gruffydd Papers, 522.  W.



	Letter, 20 Nov. 1941, from [W] Nantlais [Williams], Ammanford, concerning the evangelization of Argentina.  W. J. Gruffydd Papers, 899.  W.



	Correspondence, 1969-71, relating to Mali Evans's visit in 1970-1.  Mali Evans Papers, 52.  E, W, S.



	Letter from R. J. Berwyn, Perllenhelyg, Trerawson, Chubut, 25/2/1879, to Dr Lewis Edwards, Bala.  Thomas Charles Edwards Collection, letter 704.  W.



	Letter, 1 Nov. 1899, from Llwyd ap Iwan at Bala to the Principal, Thomas Charles Edwards.  Thomas Charles Edwards Collection, letter 5247.  W.



	A letter from Thomas C. Griffith, Treflys, Osmond Terrace, Porthmadog, sending a letter from his brother-in-law, Nadolig Jones, from South America, for Yr Herald.  Carneddog Collection, G413.  W.



	Letter, dated 10 Aug. 1906, from Griffith Griffiths, Llwyn Ebrill, Gaiman.  Relates the story of the accident which killed W. R. Jones ('Gwaenydd');  family history.  Carneddog Collection, G424.  W.



	A letter from Nadolig Jones, 29 March 1928, Leleque, Chubut, recounting the St David's Day celebrations in Buenos Aires.  Carneddog Collection, G892-4.  W.



	A letter from Nadolig Jones, Chubut, 16 Nov. 1926.  Anthropos Papers, 108.  W.



	A letter from Glynfab Williams 11 June 1927.  States that he was invited to establish a secondary school in the Welsh Colony.  Anthropos Papers, 110.  W.



	Letter, dated 1949, to the Rev. and Mrs H. T. Samuel from Mr and Mrs William Christmas Jones ('Nadolig a Gwenno'), Chubut.  The Rev. Harri Samuel Papers, 38.  W.



	Letter, 3 May 1943, from Nefydd Hughes Cadfan, Llanrwst, including memories of J. D. Evans (Patagonia).  E. Morgan Humphreys Collection, A/59.  W.



	Letter from G. Griffiths (Mold), 19 Dec. 1938, to E. Morgan Humphreys including a reference to "a Spanish book on learning English by 'Hugo'r Andes'". E. Morgan Humphreys Collection, A/1245.  W.



	Letter from Eluned Morgan (Patagonia) from Buenos Aires, 22 May 1935, inquiring whether E. Morgan Humphreys would contribute any of his books to a library in Patagonia to encourage the young people to read Welsh.  E. Morgan Humphreys Collection. A/2551.  W.



	Letter, 1923, from Thomas Shankland regarding Patagonia.  E. Morgan Humphreys Collection, A/3230.  W.



	Postcard from Nefydd Hughes Cadfan recalling the first cart that was made in the Welsh Colony by Hugh Hughes, the writer's grandfather.  His grandsons are in the picture, and a poem by him is also included.  He was one of the founders of the Welsh Colony.  [Article in Cymru'r Plant?].  Winnie Parry Collection, 21.  W.



	Letter from [Sir] O. M. Edwards to Winnie Parry.  Many people, including women in the Welsh Colony, have been enquiring about her.  Winnie Parry Collection, 87.  W.



	Letters to Kyffin Williams relating to Patagonia; under embargo till the year 2006:  Kyffin Williams Papers
	A307		Brychan Evans, Trevelin, Patagonia, 1970

	A375-7		Luned González, n.d., 1991(2)

	A386		Frederick Green, Trevelin, 1970

	A499		Emrys and Lotty Hughes, 1969

	A501-4		Glyn and May [Ceiriog Hughes], Trelew, 1970, 1971 (2), 1972

	A681		Letter from Valmai [Jones], Caergwrle, 1972

	A962		Elias Owens, Gaiman, 1978

	A1121-2		Tegai [Roberts], Gaiman, 1969, 1972

	A1268-9		Alwina H. Thomas, Buenos Aires [1969], 1992

	A1423-4		Albina J. Zampini, Gaiman, 1969, 1993





	Letters, 1966-75, to Frank Price Jones from Patagonia and from officials of Cymdeithas Cymry Ariannin in Britain.  Frank Price Jones Papers, 118.  W.



	Letter of condolence, 8 June 1933, from Eluned Morgan, Gaiman, Chubut, to the widow of the Rev. R. B. Jones, Porth, Rhondda.  R. B. Jones Papers, 4/34.  W.



	Letters and postcards from William and Hugh Pugh and their families, Trelew, Bahia Blanca, Buenos Aires, Porth Madryn, &c., 1884-1913, addressed to Richard, Ellin and Elizabeth Roberts, Blaenau Ffestiniog.  Griffith John Williams Collection.  W, E.



	Sixty letters, 1962-79, mainly in Welsh, addressed to the Rev. Norman Pritchard Williams from friends in Patagonia and other regions of Argentina.  Rev. Norman Pritchard Williams Collection.  W, E.



	Extensive references relating to Patagonia and the Welsh Patagonian Goldfields Syndicate Ltd in the correspondence of David Lloyd George.  William George Papers, 176-8207 (passim).  They include:
	a letter, 10 April 1893, to David Lloyd George, from L[ewis] Jones, Plas Hedd, Territorio Chubut.  William George Papers, 4118.  W.

	a letter, 9 Nov. 1899, from Llwyd ap Iwan, Bala, to David Lloyd George.  The disheartening news from Patagonia - the poor harvest, the lack of spirit, the obstructionist attitude of the local government which confined the founders of the Colony.  Would like to know more of the failure of the gold company.  William George Papers, 4323.  W.

	transcripts of correspondence and legal agreements, 1890-94, relating to the Welsh Patagonia Gold Fields Syndicate Ltd, together with notes in the hand of David Lloyd George endorsed (in the hand of William George) 'Commander Wood's Report on Welsh Colony'.  William George Papers, 4639.  E.





	Photocopies of Eluned Morgan's letters to William George, 1888-1930.  William George Papers, 7743-64.  W.



	Letters, 1898-1912, from Eluned Morgan to William George.  William George Papers, 7765-7844.  W.



	A letter, undated, from W. O. Hughes, Llanaelhaearn, Chwilog RSO, [?to WG] outlining his plans to go to Patagonia and his intentions for the immediate future.  William George Papers, 7848.  W.



	Letters, 1967-72, to W. R. P. George, relating to his research on Eluned Morgan and the preparation of Gyfaill Hoff.  William George Papers, 7849-79.  W.


Four copies of typescript letters from Ben Bowen Thomas, 30 Dec. 1954, concerning his recent visit to Chubut, Patagonia, including a reply from Dr Thomas Parry, Librarian, The National Library of Wales.  Sir Ben Bowen Thomas Papers, B6/6.  E, W.
 


Items catalogued by staff of the Department of Collections since 2002

	A collection of photographs of the Wladfa in the possession of the late Reverend D. D. Walters, who was a minister in Patagonia.  0200209724.



	Framed Address presented to the Reverend D. D. Walters by The Union of Free Churches, Y Wladfa, on his departure for Wales, 1922.  0200210424.



	Seven watercolours and one oil painting on canvas of Patagonian landscapes and animals by Kyffin Williams.  0200211136, 0200211145, 020021150, 020021152-3, 0200211156, 0200211179, 0200211186.



	Postcard of Hospital Britanico de Buenos Aires attended by numerous people of Welsh descent who lived in Buenos Aires either as nurses or patients.



	Twenty five post cards of various views of the Wladfa.  0200213381-2.



	Electronic copies made at NLW from photographs of the Welsh community in Y Wladfa, Argentina, which were kindly lent to the Library by the donor.  0200300377.

title: ABC
text:
ABC
	
			
Quick Search By Title

		




	
Home Page > About ABC > How To ... ABC Guides > Exhibitions > Value Added Services
	
	









	





	
	


Value added services - exhibitions

This checklist summarises the range of support services that are available to members who have 
a current Certificate of Attendance. 


Full details are available from either your Account Manager or the Exhibition Manager.


Telephone advice


Ongoing advice to cover the following areas:

	Design and approval of registration documentation
	
	Rule queries
	
	Best practice




Consultation visits


Visits are available to either your office or those of your registration bureaus to discuss:

	Record management
	
	Advice on return submissions 
	
	Training


 

Workshops


Held either at ABC or at your own premises workshops cover:

	Understanding the Certificate of Attendance audit schemes
	
	The audit process, how it works and how to prepare for it
	
	Completing the Return Form
	
	ABC marketing assistance for organisers




Presentations


Presentations to explain the purpose and value of the audit to:

	Sales Teams - how to use the certificates as a cost effective sales & marketing tool
	
	Exhibitors - the value of auditing which can take the form of attendance at the 
	exhibition or participation in pre-exhibitor days




Marketing


The exhibition scheme benefits from the corporate marketing of ABC with bespoke activities in 
the following areas:


	Sponsorship of Industry Events
	
	Advertising campaign with the trade press
	
	Availability of figures to both buyers & sellers on www.abc.org.uk 
	
	LUKE & www.Expo24-7.com




In addition bespoke marketing support is available:


	Direct mail campaign - 'Don't Make an Exhibition of Yourself'
	
	Tailored individual direct mail pieces on ABC letterhead with a bespoke message 
	about your show




More information


For more information please do not hesitate to contact your Account Manager.


Details of who your Account Manager is can be obtained from Chris Skeith, Sales & Exhibition Manager:

Email - chris.skeith@abc.org.uk
ABC

Card Watch raises awareness about all types of plastic card fraud in the UK, and provides information to prevent fraudulent use of credit cards, debit cards, cheque guarantee cards and charge cards. 

 







In addition, Card Watch provides training for retailers, police and bank staff and contributes to the fight against plastic card fraud, headed by the Dedicated Cheque and Plastic Crime Unit and the Fraud Intelligence Bureau. 

 

Here you will find comprehensive information about plastic card fraud, free publications and training materials, useful tips and answers to your frequently asked questions.

 






 WARNING: PIN NUMBER REVERSAL EMAIL IS A MYTH



				
				
				
				
              

              



			
	 		  	 
                      	 
                  

	
	 
                   
                    Click here for information aimed at retailers who accept payments where the card is not present  - such as online, mail order or telephone transactions.
